media.description: Mike Trout, playing at Citi Field on Friday night, is everything good about his sport.
media.credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
description: At the age of 25, the Angels’ Trout is among the game’s best. One thing he’s not, though, is anyone’s idea of a swaggering self-promoter.
dc.creator: TYLER KEPNER

title: Mets Seek to Gain Control of a Season in Danger of Slipping Away
media.description: The Mets’ rotation, including, from left, Noah Syndergaard, Jacob deGrom and Matt Harvey, has faced injuries and inconsistency.
media.credit: Noah K. Murray/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: Playing 12 of their next 16 games at home, the Mets hope to make up some ground after losing seven in a row.
dc.creator: SETH BERKMAN

title: Rays 5, Yankees 4: Joe Girardi Preaches About Family. On Friday, He Practiced It.
media.description: Joe Girardi had been in the Yankees’ dugout for all but three games in his 10-year tenure as manager. On Friday against the Rays, the longtime bench coach Rob Thomson served as manager.
description: Girardi, the Yankees’ manager, missed a game against the Rays to attend the high school graduation of his oldest daughter in South Florida.
dc.creator: BILLY WITZ

title: Mets 3, Angels 0: Jacob deGrom Goes Seven Innings as Mets Halt a Seven-Game Skid
media.description: Jacob deGrom threw seven scoreless innings to help the Mets end a seven-game losing streak with a 3-0 win over the Angels on Friday night.
description: DeGrom struck out nine as the Mets shut out the Angels at Citi Field. DeGrom became the first Mets pitcher to go more than six innings since he went seven on April 28.
dc.creator: SETH BERKMAN

title: Royals 5, Yankees 1: Royals Silence Previously Potent Yankees Lineup
media.description: Jacoby Ellsbury beating the throw to the Royals’ Eric Hosmer on a bunt, one of three Yankees hits in the first seven innings.
media.credit: Peter Aiken/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: The Kansas City left-hander Danny Duffy, the opposite of a Yankee killer in the past, struck out 10 batters in seven scoreless innings and allowed only three hits.
dc.creator: PAT BORZI

title: Commissioner Says Miami Marlins’ Sale Is Moving Forward
media.description: Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred during a February news conference. On Thursday, Manfred said that two bidders for the Miami Marlins have similarly priced offers.
description: Two bidders for the team, including a group headed by Derek Jeter and Jeb Bush, ‘are in relatively the same place in terms of price,’ Rob Manfred said.
dc.creator: WALLACE MATTHEWS

title: Blue Jays’ Kevin Pillar Is Suspended Two Games for Anti-Gay Slur
media.description: Kevin Pillar of the Blue Jays during a game in Anaheim, Calif., last month.
media.credit: Gary A. Vasquez/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: Toronto suspended the center fielder after he yelled the slur at Atlanta Braves pitcher Jason Motte during a game Wednesday night.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Yankees 11, Royals 7: Yankees Add Speed to Their Power and Throttle the Royals
media.description: Brett Gardner, the Yankees’ leadoff hitter, scoring behind Royals catcher Salvador Perez on a first-inning double by Starlin Castro.
media.credit: Jay Biggerstaff/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: Aggressive base running helped the Yankees score twice early, and Aaron Hicks hit a three-run homer in a five-run fourth inning in a victory over Kansas City.
dc.creator: PAT BORZI

title: Sports Briefing: Lance McCullers Helps Astros Complete Sweep of Marlins
media.description: Houston’s Lance McCullers held Miami to three hits and wore a tribute to Jose Fernandez on his cleats during Wednesday’s game.
description: McCullers allowed no earned runs for the third start in a row, limiting the Marlins to three hits in six innings in a 3-0 victory as Houston improved to 29-12.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Diamondbacks 5, Mets 4: Matt Harvey Makes Progress, but Mets’ Beleaguered Bullpen Falters Again
media.description: The Arizona Diamondbacks on Wednesday after a game-ending home run by Chris Herrmann, second from right, against Rafael Montero. Herrmann was the first batter Montero faced.
description: Rafael Montero gave up a game-ending home run to Chris Herrmann in the bottom of the 11th. It was the Mets’ season-high seventh consecutive loss.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Alex Rodriguez, Still Tied to the Yankees, Will Now Analyze Them on TV
media.description: Alex Rodriguez, shown during the 2015 World Series, will make his debut as an in-game analyst Thursday night for Fox Sports 1.
description: Rodriguez, retired as a player but still being paid $21 million by the team in the last year of a 2007 deal, remains a Yankees adviser but will be in the broadcast booth for a game against the Royals.
dc.creator: WALLACE MATTHEWS

title: Diamondbacks 5, Mets 4: With Sixth Straight Loss, Mets Sink to a Low Not Seen Since 2014
media.description: Lucas Duda has struggled both at the plate and at first base. “I’ve been bad at baseball for the last week,” he said.
description: There’s plenty of time to get the season back on track, but the latest defeat against the Diamondbacks put the Mets six games below .500.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Yankees 7, Royals 1: Easy Win by Yankees Delays a Test of Dellin Betances
media.description: C. C. Sabathia, pitching in the first, threw six and two-thirds scoreless innings and improved to 3-2 in beating the Royals.
media.credit: Jay Biggerstaff/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: C. C. Sabathia pitched six and two-thirds scoreless innings, and Gary Sanchez hit a three-run homer, so Betances wasn’t needed in his new role as closer.
dc.creator: PAT BORZI

title: Keeping Score: Mets, Once in the Pitching Penthouse, Are Evicted Early
media.description: Mets starter Matt Harvey ran afoul of the team when he failed to show up for a game. He received a three-day suspension.
description: Injuries, struggles on the mound and off-the-field issues have turned a starting rotation that appeared to be the team’s strength into its surprising Achilles’ heel.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Diamondbacks 7, Mets 3: Mets’ Pitching Problems Are Laid Bare in Loss to Diamondbacks
media.description: Rene Rivera of the Mets hit an R.B.I. single against the Diamondbacks on Monday.
description: The 7-3 defeat on Monday, their fifth loss in a row, was the second straight game squandered in the eighth, shining a light on the already strained bullpen.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Asdrubal Cabrera’s Thumb Injury Is a Lingering Problem for the Mets
media.description: Asdrubal Cabrera, who has a thumb injury, was not in the lineup against Arizona on Monday.
description: Cabrera, the starting shortstop, first hurt his left thumb on May 6 but has aggravated the injury since, and the team is weighing whether he needs to go on the 10-day disabled list.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Mark Reynolds Becomes a Pleasant Surprise for the Rockies
media.description: Mark Reynolds, signed to a minor league deal in the off-season, is driving the Rockies’ offense, hitting .326 with 12 home runs.
description: Signed to a minor league deal in February, Reynolds was not expected to be a regular starter, but he is hitting .326 with 12 homers and 33 R.B.I.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Steve Palermo, Umpire Whose Career Was Ended by a Bullet, Dies at 67
media.description: Steve Palermo, an American League umpire for 15 years, in 1982. He was shot in 1991.
description: Mr. Palermo was shot in 1991 while defending two waitresses from an attack outside a Dallas restaurant. He lived in chronic pain but had no regrets.
dc.creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

title: Terry Collins, Soon to Be the Mets’ Longest-Tenured Manager, Still Relishes the Job
media.description: Terry Collins, who became the Mets’ manager in 2011, will become the team’s longest-tenured manager when he leads the team in his 1,013th game.
description: Collins is set to pass Davey Johnson when he manages his 1,013th game. During his time in New York, Collins has adopted a mellower approach to deal with a stress-filled job.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Yankees and Astros Split Doubleheader on Derek Jeter Night
media.description: Celebration was the theme of the fourth inning of Game 1 for, from left, the Yankees’ Didi Gregorius, Starlin Castro, Aaron Judge and Matt Holliday.
description: The Yankees won the opener behind big blows from Starlin Castro, Aaron Judge and Chase Headley, but the Astros abruptly broke up the festivities with three home runs in the first inning of the nightcap.
dc.creator: WALLACE MATTHEWS

title: Derek Jeter Becomes the Yankees’ Newest Immortal
media.description: Derek Jeter unveiled his plaque on Sunday.
media.credit: Jason Szenes for The New York Times
description: In a ceremony attended by his wife, former teammates, managers, coaches and “the greatest fans in the history of sports,” Jeter took his place in Monument Park.
dc.creator: WALLACE MATTHEWS

title: On Baseball: Derek Jeter, Out of Pinstripes and in Monument Park, Can Finally Reflect
media.description: Derek Jeter, who played 20 seasons in New York, during Sunday’s event at sold-out Yankee Stadium, where fans chanted his name. He called the Yankees “the only team I ever wanted to play for.”
media.credit: Jason Szenes for The New York Times
description: The shortstop was famous during his 20-year career for staying in the moment. But as the Yankees retired his No. 2 jersey on Sunday, he could, at last, ponder his place in baseball history.
dc.creator: TYLER KEPNER

title: Brewers 11, Mets 9: Mets Build a Six-Run Lead, Then Lose by Two
media.description: Milwaukee’s Manny Pina hit a three-run homer off Addison Reed in the eighth inning to cap the Brewers’ big comeback.
description: The Mets led, 7-1, after five innings, but that was not enough for Jacob deGrom and a string of relievers.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Aroldis Chapman Is on the Disabled List and May Be Out for a Month
media.description: The Yankees’ closer, Aroldis Chapman, with catcher Gary Sanchez, was checked out by the team trainer, Steve Donohue, in the ninth inning of Friday’s game.
description: An M.R.I. on Saturday revealed inflammation in the rotator cuff of the Yankees closer’s left shoulder. He had complained of pain on Friday night.
dc.creator: WALLACE MATTHEWS

title: Derek Jeter Set to Take His Place in Monument Park. But Where Exactly?
media.description: Fans visiting Monument Park at Yankee Stadium before the Yankees’ season opener in 2015. On Sunday, Derek Jeter will have his plaque and his number unveiled there.
media.credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
description: As fans toured the Stadium shrine days before the Yankees were to unveil Jeter’s plaque and retire his No. 2, it was a secret where the markers would go.
dc.creator: DAVID WALDSTEIN

title: Brewers 11, Mets 4: Mets’ Pitching Betrays Them Again in a Loss to the Brewers
media.description: Jett Bandy beating the tag from Mets catcher Kevin Plawecki to score in the fifth inning. Mets starter Robert Gsellman and reliever Hansel Robles gave up a total of eight runs in that inning.
description: Starter Robert Gsellman could not get an out in the fifth inning as the Mets’ once-fearsome rotation continued to falter.
dc.creator: JAMES WAGNER

title: Hamidou Diallo Hasn’t Played a Game in Months. But His Draft Stock Is Rising.
media.description: “The more you don’t play, the more they like you, the more they’re impressed,” said, John Calipari, coach to Hamidou Diallo at the University of Kentucky. Diallo, shown in August in New York, has not played since enrolling in January.
description: Diallo, now at Kentucky and known for his athleticism, has not played an official game since before Christmas, but his stock appears to be rising as the draft approaches.
dc.creator: ADAM ZAGORIA

title: Prosecutors Taking Tougher Stance in Fraternity Hazing Deaths
media.description: The Centre County, Pa., district attorney, Stacy Parks Miller, left, with Jim and Evelyn Piazza at a news conference on Friday where she announced the results of an investigation into the death of their son Timothy Piazza.
media.credit: Abby Drey/Centre Daily Times, via Associated Press
description: Eighteen Penn State students have been charged in the death of a sophomore: a case that, not so long ago, might have resulted only in hand-wringing.
dc.creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

title: Si Woo Kim, 21, Claims the Players Championship
media.description: Si Woo Kim shot a three-under 69 on Sunday to win the Players Championship for his second PGA Tour title.
description: Kim, a South Korean, is the youngest winner of the tournament, which featured 48 of the world’s top 50 players.
dc.creator: KAREN CROUSE

title: Unforgiving Course Inflates Scores at the Players Championship
media.description: J. B. Holmes putting on the 18th green during the third round of the Players Championship. He used his putter to erase a number of mistakes and head into the final round tied for the lead.
description: A blustery southern wind brought havoc to the third round at T.P.C. Sawgrass. J. B. Holmes and Kyle Stanley headed into the final round atop the leaderboard.
dc.creator: KAREN CROUSE

title: On Golf: A Hush Over Punishments on the PGA Tour Leads Only to Whispers
media.description: Jay Monahan, the PGA Tour commissioner, said the tour and its players were discussing increased transparency.
description: The tour has long kept quiet when its players misbehave, favoring secrecy over public penalties. But the modern game requires transparency.
dc.creator: KAREN CROUSE

title: Jon Rahm, Golf’s Next Big Thing, Has Already Arrived
media.description: Jon Rahm hitting from the 14th fairway during the second round of the Players Championship on Friday. After shooting a 72, he was five strokes back.
description: A 22-year-old Spaniard by way of Arizona State, Rahm’s meteoric rise has placed him at No. 12 in the Official World Golf Ranking.
dc.creator: ADAM SCHUPAK

title: How a Golf Course Is Reshaping a New Orleans Neighborhood
media.description: Claudette Ashford and her son, Jonathan, 9, outside their home in Columbia Parc, close to Bayou Oaks. “It’s like having a golf course in your backyard,” she said.
media.credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
description: The newly opened South Course at Bayou Oaks and Columbia Parc, a mixed-income development, rose from the ruins of Hurricane Katrina.
dc.creator: ADAM SCHUPAK

title: Penguins 3, Senators 2 | Series tied, 2-2: Resurgent Sidney Crosby Leads Penguins Past Senators
media.description: Sidney Crosby tucked the puck past Senators goaltender Craig Anderson during the second period on Friday.
media.credit: Sean Kilpatrick/Canadian Press, via Associated Press
description: Crosby, who had just 1 point through the first three games of the series, recorded a goal and an assist in Pittsburgh’s Game 4 victory.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Ducks 3, Predators 2 | Series tied, 2-2: Deflection in Overtime Lifts Ducks After a Late Advantage Is Lost
media.description: Predators defenseman P.K. Subban after his team’s 10-game postseason winning streak at home ended on a deflected overtime goal.
media.credit: Christopher Hanewinckel/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: Corey Perry scored 10:25 into overtime with a shot that hit P.K. Subban’s stick, and the Ducks ended the Predators’ 10-game home playoff winning streak.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Penguins Go From Murray to Fleury, to Murray?
media.description: Marc-Andre Fleury had been strong for the Pittsburgh Penguins during the playoffs until allowing four goals in less than 13 minutes in Wednesday’s Game 3 loss to the Ottawa Senators.
description: Pittsburgh has not announced if Matt Murray will replace Marc-Andre Fleury in goal for Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals against Ottawa.
dc.creator: LISA BURKE-WALLACE

title: Senators 5, Penguins 1: Senators Chase Marc-Andre Fleury and Overwhelm Injury-Riddled Penguins
media.description: Derick Brassard beating Penguins goalie Marc-Andre Fleury for one of the Senators’ four first-period goals Wednesday night.
media.credit: Sean Kilpatrick/Canadian Press, via Associated Press
description: Host Ottawa had four first-period goals, the last three in 2 minutes 18 seconds, and took a 2-1 lead in the Eastern Conference finals.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: N.H.L.’s Goaltending Merry-Go-Round Gets an Early Start
media.description: #NA
description: With the Vegas Golden Knights expansion draft as a catalyst and plenty of teams in the market for talent in the net, the dominoes were starting to fall.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Predators 2, Ducks 1: Predators Score Twice in Third Period and Take Series Lead Over Ducks
media.description: Filip Forsberg of the Predators fell into the goal mouth after scoring for Nashville during the third period on Tuesday.
description: Roman Josi and Filip Forsberg scored for Nashville as it rallied from a 1-0 deficit entering the final period.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Only Two Goals in Two Games, but Penguins Say the Chances Are There
media.description: Senators goalie Craig Anderson, right, making a save against the Penguins in Game 2 of the N.H.L.’s Eastern Conference finals on Monday. The series is tied, one game apiece.
description: Before the Senators’ trap stifled the high-scoring Penguins in the first two games of the conference finals, they had not been held to a single goal in a game in seven weeks.
dc.creator: CHRIS ADAMSKI

title: Penguins 1, Senators 0: Phil Kessel’s Goal Lifts Penguins to Even Series With Senators
media.description: Phil Kessel, left, with Chris Kunitz and Evgeni Malkin after Kessel’s goal put the Pittsburgh Penguins ahead on Monday.
description: Kessel scored just over 13 minutes into the third period after the Penguins had dominated long stretches of Game 2 on Monday.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: On the N.H.L.’s Playoff Ice, Injuries Are Risen Above
media.description: Pittsburgh’s Sidney Crosby sustained a concussion and an apparent lower-body injury in the playoffs against Washington, but he missed just one game.
description: With their eyes on the Stanley Cup, players have traditionally kept their broken bones and torn ligaments to themselves until after their teams are eliminated.
dc.creator: ANDREW KNOLL

title: Ducks Start Slow but Finish Strong to Tie Western Conference Finals
media.description: Anaheim goalie John Gibson defending the goal against Nashville on Sunday night. He finished with 30 saves, outplaying his Predators counterpart, Pekka Rinne.
media.credit: Gary A. Vasquez/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: After having lost in overtime in the opener, the Ducks fell behind by two goals early on before a furious rally gave them Game 2.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Are Olympic Fans Set for Men’s Hockey Without Players From the N.H.L.?
media.description: A match between Norway and Slovenia in Paris on Tuesday during the world championship tournament.
description: The league announced last month that it would not release players for the Winter Games, and teams preparing for 2018 are struggling to adjust.
dc.creator: SALIM VALJI and JULIE ROBENHYMER

title: Senators 2, Penguins 1 | Overtime | Ottawa leads Eastern Conference finals, 1-0: Bobby Ryan Scores on a Breakaway to Give Ottawa the Win in Game 1
media.description: Alex Burrows (14) of the Ottawa Senators preparing to take a shot on Pittsburgh goalie Marc-Andre Fleury (29) during the third period of Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.
description: The Senators are now 6-1 in overtime during this postseason, and the Penguins are trailing in a series for the first time.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: On Pro Basketball: Bring On the Monstars: Another Rout Shows LeBron James Is on Jordan’s Level
media.description: LeBron James blocks Avery Bradley’s lay-up on the way to Cleveland’s 130-86 victory over the Celtics in Boston on Friday in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference Finals.
description: As the Cleveland Cavaliers blow through the N.B.A. playoffs, it’s time to admit that James has reached the same celestial level of a certain “Space Jam” star, an achievement worth celebrating.
dc.creator: HARVEY ARATON

title: N.B.A. Player Enes Kanter Released After Being Held in Romania
media.description: Enes Kanter of the Oklahoma City Thunder said in a video posted on Twitter that the authorities in Romania had detained him and told him his passport had been canceled.
description: Kanter, a Turk, posted a video on Twitter from an airport saying his passport was canceled because he opposes President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whom he called “the Hitler of our century.”
dc.creator: BENJAMIN HOFFMAN

title: W.N.B.A. Is Helping Officials Raise Their Game
media.description: The Sparks’ Nneka Ogwumike in Game 5 of the W.N.B.A. finals. She made a late field goal after officials missed a shot-clock violation, the league said.
description: The league is increasing training for referees after missed calls in last season’s playoffs led to widespread criticism.
dc.creator: SETH BERKMAN

title: Kevin Durant Is Certain Kawhi Leonard Will Play — ‘100 Percent’
media.description: The Spurs’ Kawhi Leonard grabbing a rebound against the Warriors’ Kevin Durant in Game 1 of the conference finals, in which Leonard aggravated an ankle sprain.
media.credit: Kyle Terada/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: The San Antonio Spurs are listing Leonard, their injured star, as “questionable” for Game 3 on Saturday night.
dc.creator: SCOTT CACCIOLA

title: Cavaliers 130, Celtics 86 | Cleveland leads series, 2-0: Cavaliers Build 41-Point Halftime Lead and Crush the Celtics
media.description: Forward Kevin Love dunking in the first half as the Cavaliers built a 41-point halftime lead, setting an N.B.A. playoff record.
media.credit: Winslow Townson/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: Isaiah Thomas was lost to a strained right hip for the second half, but the game had already been decided. Cleveland’s halftime lead set an N.B.A. playoff record.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: N.B.A. Announces M.V.P. Finalists, and LeBron James Is Not Included
media.description: Russell Westbrook, right, and James Harden during Game 5 of a first-round playoff series on April 25.
media.credit: Thomas Shea/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: Russell Westbrook, James Harden and Kawhi Leonard are on the short list for the award.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: From Spurs to Warriors, David West Targets First Title With Precision
media.description: Golden State’s David West, right, with Stephen Curry. “He’s a class act,” San Antonio Coach Gregg Popovich said of West.
description: West, a 14-year veteran, played for San Antonio’s Gregg Popovich last year. Now he’s in Golden State’s star-studded lineup, providing assists off the bench.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Keeping Score: The Irresistible Cavaliers. The Immovable Warriors.
media.description: Game 7 of last year’s finals, with the Warriors’ Stephen Curry and the Cavs’ LeBron James.
media.credit: Bob Donnan/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: With their regular-season blips behind them, both teams are tearing through the playoffs and seem headed toward a Finals rematch.
dc.creator: VICTOR MATHER

title: LeBron James Ties Record With 11th All-N.B.A. First Team
media.description: LeBron James was named to the All-N.B.A. first team for the 11th time, tying a record shared by Karl Malone and Kobe Bryant.
media.credit: Nick Turchiaro/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
description: James Harden was the only unanimous choice for the first team, which also included Russell Westbrook, Kawhi Leonard and Anthony Davis.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: San Antonio Bets Its Small Stars Can Be Supernovas
media.description: Kelsey Plum, right, with the Washington Huskies in February. The San Antonio Stars selected the 5-foot-8 Plum as the No. 1 draft pick.
description: Despite its depth at guard, San Antonio took 5-foot-8 Kelsey Plum with the No. 1 draft pick, making for a size-disadvantaged, but promising, team.
dc.creator: HOWARD MEGDAL

title: Cavaliers 117, Celtics 104: Cavaliers Overwhelm Celtics in Game 1
media.description: Isaiah Thomas of the Celtics was swarmed by Cavaliers players on a drive to the basket during the first half of Cleveland’s win on Wednesday.
description: LeBron James scored 38 points, Kevin Love added 32, and Boston was never really close in a dominant performance by Cleveland.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: On Pro Basketball: Spurs Get Gregg Popovich’s Message, to Their Detriment
media.description: The Spurs’ bench during a 136-100 loss to the Warriors on Tuesday in Game 2 of the Western Conference finals. Game 3 is on Saturday in San Antonio.
description: The San Antonio coach’s negative statements before Game 2 became a self-fulfilling prophecy in a 136-100 loss to the Warriors on Tuesday.
dc.creator: SCOTT CACCIOLA

title: On Pro Basketball: It’s Back to the Future for the Celtics, the Sixers and the Lakers
media.description: Mark Tatum, far left, the N.B.A. deputy commissioner, with representatives for the teams selecting 1-2-3 in the coming draft: from left, Wyc Grousbeck (Celtics), Magic Johnson (Lakers) and Joel Embiid (76ers).
description: It is not hard to imagine a day soon when the Celtics and the 76ers are grappling for supremacy in the East, with the Lakers awaiting the winner, just like in the 1980s.
dc.creator: HARVEY ARATON

title: Frank Brian, Standout in N.B.A.’s Early Years, Dies at 94
media.description: Frank Brian in 1950. He was twice an All-Star in the N.B.A.
media.credit: NBA Photo Library, via Getty Images
description: Slight by current N.B.A. standards at 6 feet 1 inches and about 175 pounds, Mr. Brian was known as a versatile guard at L.S.U. and as a professional.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Warriors 136, Spurs 100: Warriors Take 2-0 Series Lead with a Blowout of the Spurs
media.description: The Spurs’ LaMarcus Aldridge fought for position against the Warriors during Game 2 of the Western Conference finals.
description: Stephen Curry scored 29 points for Golden State, and the Warriors never trailed in Game 2 as San Antonio sorely missed the hobbled Kawhi Leonard.
dc.creator: SCOTT CACCIOLA

title: N.B.A. Draft Lottery: Celtics, Already No. 1 in the East, Add Pick No. 1
media.description: The 2015 N.B.A. draft lottery in New York. The Boston Celtics were awarded the top pick on Tuesday in the 2017 draft lottery.
media.credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
description: The Celtics finished this regular season as the top team in the Eastern Conference but had good odds in the lottery because of a 2013 trade with the Nets.
dc.creator: MIKE VORKUNOV

title: After a Grueling Series, Underdog Celtics Gird for Rested Cavaliers
media.description: Kelly Olynyk of the Boston Celtics after the team defeated the Washington Wizards and advanced to the Eastern Conference finals for the first time since 2012.
description: It took until the fourth quarter for the Celtics to pull away from the Washington Wizards on Monday night in Game 7 of the closely contested Eastern Conference semifinals.
dc.creator: PETER MAY

title: Celtics 115, Wizards 105: Celtics Close Out the Wizards as Isaiah Thomas Scores 29
media.description: Boston’s Isaiah Thomas, right, and Washington’s John Wall during the first half of Game 7. Thomas led the Celtics with 29 points and added 12 assists.
description: Boston advanced to the Eastern Conference finals, where it will meet the defending champion Cleveland Cavaliers. Game 1 is scheduled for Wednesday on the Celtics’ home floor.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: On Pro Basketball: Warriors’ Zaza Pachulia Draws Spurs’ Ire Over Key Play
media.description: Zaza Pachulia after being called for a foul in Game 1 on Sunday. In contesting a shot by Kawhi Leonard, he led Leonard to reinjure his ankle.
description: In contesting a long shot by Kawhi Leonard, Pachulia, a center, led Leonard to land awkwardly and reinjure his ankle in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals.
dc.creator: SCOTT CACCIOLA

title: N.B.A. Draft Lottery 2017: Boston Celtics Have Best Chance for Top Pick
media.description: In 2015, Mark Tatum, the N.B.A.’s deputy commissioner, announced that the Knicks had secured the fourth pick in the draft lottery.
media.credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
description: The lottery, which determines the critical top three picks in the draft order, will be held Tuesday night in New York.
dc.creator: VICTOR MATHER

title: On Pro Basketball: After Steve Kerr’s Halftime Speech, the Warriors Rally Past the Spurs
media.description: The Warriors have coped with the health-related absence of Coach Steve Kerr in the playoffs the way they did the loss of Kevin Durant for 19 games in the regular season.
description: Golden State, still without its coach on the bench, trailed by as many as 25 points, but won Game 1 of the Western Conference finals.
dc.creator: SCOTT CACCIOLA

title: Liberty 73, Stars 64: Liberty Win Home Opener, Topping the Stars and a Former Teammate
media.description: Vickie Johnson after a San Antonio Stars practice Friday at Madison Square Garden. Johnson, a former Liberty player, made her debut Saturday as the Stars’ head coach.
description: Vickie Johnson, San Antonio’s new coach, played for the Liberty and is their career leader in scoring, rebounds and games played.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Ryan Fitzpatrick Signs With Tampa Bay Buccaneers
media.description: Quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick has spent 12 seasons in the N.F.L., most recently with the Jets.
description: Fitzpatrick, who has bounced around the league for 12 seasons, will back up the starting quarterback, Jameis Winston.
dc.creator: VICTOR MATHER

title: LeGarrette Blount Agrees to One-Year Deal With Eagles
media.description: LeGarrette Blount led the N.F.L. with 18 touchdowns last season.
description: Blount, who led the N.F.L. with 18 rushing touchdowns for the Patriots last season, gives the Eagles a bruising back to complement their group of speedy runners.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: For Carson Palmer, Secret to Success May Be Throwing Less
media.description: Cardinals quarterback Carson Palmer (3) and Blaine Gabbert, a backup, on Tuesday.
description: The 37-year-old Cardinals quarterback has laid off passing in the off-season, and he plans to continue placing some limits on it in practices, to try to keep his arm fresh.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Yale Lary, a Force on the Detroit Lions’ Title-Winning Teams of the 1950s, Dies at 86
media.description: Lary punting for the Lions against the Los Angeles Rams in the 1960s. Lary developed his punting skills in junior high school by practicing outside his home at night.
media.credit: National Football League, via Associated Press
description: Lary, a Hall of Famer, was a safety and a punter. Although he was small, his “speed and quickness made him a real ballhawk,” said Raymond Berry, a Hall of Fame receiver for the Baltimore Colts.
dc.creator: RICHARD GOLDSTEIN

title: A Showcase Match Falls Flat as Two M.L.S. Linchpins Search for Answers
media.description: The Los Angeles Galaxy’s Romain Alessandrini scored two goals in the first 10 minutes of the game on Sunday, but few people were there to see it, as empty seats outnumbered occupied ones at Red Bull Arena.
media.credit: Ira L. Black/Corbis, via Getty Images
description: Sunday’s Red Bulls-Galaxy matchup, once one of the biggest dates on the M.L.S. calendar, fell victim to two teams in transition.
dc.creator: JACK WILLIAMS

title: Tottenham Tops Manchester United in White Hart Lane Finale
media.description: Tottenham fans took the field after the team’s victory over Manchester United on Sunday in Hotspur’s final game at White Hart Lane, the team’s home of 118 years.
description: Tottenham Hotspur said a victorious goodbye to their home of 118 years while ensuring themselves the runner-up spot in the Premier League, the club’s highest finish in 54 years.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Chelsea 1, West Bromwich Albion 0: Chelsea, by Besting the Rank and File, Wins the Premier League Title
media.description: David Luiz, top, celebrating with his Chelsea teammates after Michy Batshuayi scored in their 1-0 win over West Bromwich Albion on Friday.
description: By defeating West Bromwich Albion, and other teams like it, Chelsea put any notion that its title run was in jeopardy to rest on Friday with a 1-0 victory.
dc.creator: RORY SMITH

title: At Italy’s Coaching Academy, a Pipeline of Champions
media.description: Renzo Ulivieri coaching on the field at Coverciano. There is no “perfect football,” he said, only the right football for the right moment.
media.credit: Clara Vannucci for The New York Times
description: Aspiring coaches continue to be drawn to Scuola Allenatori in Coverciano, where instructors focus not on what worked before, but on what will work next.
dc.creator: RORY SMITH

title: On Soccer: Paul Pogba Can’t Save Manchester United Alone. Nobody Can.
media.description: Paul Pogba returned to Manchester United after the club paid a record transfer fee of nearly 90 million pounds.
description: English soccer’s obsession with the individual over the team is projected onto the world’s most expensive player.
dc.creator: RORY SMITH

title: Sports Briefing: Venus Williams Falls in the Italian Open Quarterfinals
media.description: Garbiñe Muguruza, the No. 3 seed, serving during her three-set victory over Venus Williams in Rome.
description: Williams lost to Garbiñe Muguruza, the third seed and the defending French Open champion, in three sets.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Dominant on Clay, Rafael Nadal Hits a Bump Before the French Open
media.description: Rafael Nadal after a point during his loss to Dominic Thiem in Rome. Nadal is still the heavy favorite in the men’s draw at the French Open.
description: Nadal has reasserted himself as one of the top players in tennis, but he lost in the Italian Open quarterfinals to the up-and-coming Dominic Thiem.
dc.creator: BEN ROTHENBERG

title: Murray and Kerber Are No. 1, but Not at the Top of Their Games
media.description: Angelique Kerber during her fourth-round loss to Coco Vandeweghe at the Australian Open.
description: Andy Murray and Angelique Kerber are heading toward the French Open with no momentum after losing their opening matches this week at the Italian Open.
dc.creator: BEN ROTHENBERG

title: Denying Maria Sharapova, Inviting a Debate
media.description: Maria Sharapova playing in the Italian Open in Rome this week.
description: The French Tennis Federation’s call not to give Sharapova a wild card into the French Open has some claiming it went too far.
dc.creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY

title: Maria Sharapova Is Denied a Wild-Card Spot in the French Open
media.description: Maria Sharapova during her victory over Christina McHale at the Italian Open on Monday.
description: Sharapova, who recently returned from a doping suspension, now has no way of entering the French Open, which she has won twice.
dc.creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY

title: Roger Federer Decides to Skip the French Open
media.description: Roger Federer after winning the Australian Open, the first tennis major of the year. He will miss the second major, the French Open.
description: Federer, who has won a major among three titles this year at 35, is bypassing the clay-court season entirely to prepare for Wimbledon.
dc.creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY

title: Sharapova, Foot in Door at Wimbledon, Awaits Approval to Play French Open
media.description: Maria Sharapova during her first-round victory over Christina McHale at the Italian Open in Rome.
description: Maria Sharapova, back from a 15-month doping-related ban, has secured direct entry into the Wimbledon qualifying draw, but still needs a wild-card entry to Paris, the coming Grand Slam event.
dc.creator: BEN ROTHENBERG

title: Police Officer Who Manhandled Tennis Star James Blake Avoids Trial
media.description: Officer James Frascatore, who is said to have reached a deal that spares him a public disciplinary trial over accusations he used excessive force in the wrongful arrest of James Blake.
description: James Frascatore has reached an agreement that will allow him to avoid a public disciplinary trial over his mistaken, and rough, arrest of Mr. Blake in Manhattan in 2015.
dc.creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL
category.1: Frascatore, James (New York, NY, Police Officer)

title: Trilobites: Ladybugs Pack Wings and Engineering Secrets in Tidy Origami Packages
media.description: After ladybugs fly, they tuck their wings into a sliver of space between their abdomen and the colorful outer wings for which they are best known.
description: Using high-speed cameras, a transparent artificial wing and other techniques, researchers in Japan created a window into how ladybugs fold their wings.
dc.creator: JOANNA KLEIN
category.2: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

title: Trilobites: Genetic Tidying Up Made Humped Bladderworts Into Carnivorous Plants
media.description: An image of a humped bladderwort.
description: A new study identifies the evolutionary refinements that gave rise to floating, rootless plants that can trap and digest, like super-fast Venus flytraps.
dc.creator: JOANNA KLEIN
category.2: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

title: Trilobites: Spotting Mysterious Twinkles on Earth From a Million Miles Away
media.description: An image from the Dscovr satellite, taken on Dec. 3, 2015, shows a glint over central South America.
description: Hundreds of reflections observed by a satellite are a result of ice crystals floating in clouds at high altitudes, NASA scientists say.
dc.creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

title: Trilobites: Between a T. Rex’s Powerful Jaws, Bones of Its Prey Exploded
media.description: New research suggests that the Tyrannosaurus rex crushed its prey with 7,800 pounds of force.
description: Paleontologists calculated the bite force of the fearsome prehistoric predators and provided more evidence that they were opportunistic scavengers.
dc.creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

title: Trilobites: Nearly a Decade Nursing? Study Pierces Orangutans’ Mother-Child Bond
media.description: A wild orangutan with her 11-month-old infant in Borneo. Orangutans sometimes nurse into their ninth year of life, a study found, possibly because of environmental fluctuations in food, with unpredictable booms and busts in fruit.
description: Researchers think they may have found a clue for why the critically endangered apes nurse longer than any other mammal: environmental fluctuations in food.
dc.creator: STEPH YIN

title: Profiles in Science: Brenda Milner, Eminent Brain Scientist, Is ‘Still Nosy’ at 98
media.description: Dr. Brenda Milner in her office at the Montreal Neurological Institute and Hospital last month.
media.credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
description: Seven decades after she began, Dr. Milner continues to explore the biology of memory and how the brain’s many parts function together.
dc.creator: BENEDICT CAREY

title: A Remote Pacific Island Awash in Tons of Trash
media.description: Trash on East Beach, Henderson Island, in the South Pacific Ocean. A new study estimated that the white sand beaches were littered with 17.6 tons of debris, deposited there by ocean currents.
media.credit: Jennifer Lavers/Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies, via European Pressphoto Agency
description: A survey of uninhabited Henderson Island in the South Pacific estimated that about 17.6 tons of debris had washed ashore, endangering wildlife and blighting beaches.
dc.creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
category.5: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

title: ScienceTake: Why Honeybees Are Good at Grooming (It’s All in the Hair)
media.description: #NA
description: Researchers at Georgia Tech found that a bee could shed about 15,000 pollen grains in two minutes as it brushed itself clean.
dc.creator: JAMES GORMAN

title: Freezing Temperatures, Glacial Winds, Volcanic Dust: All in a Day’s Work for Times Team in Antarctica
media.description: McMurdo Station scientists and support staff wait on the Ross Ice Shelf to observe a NASA balloon launch.
description: The story behind the story of the first virtual-reality stereo footage ever shot on the continent.
dc.creator: JONATHAN CORUM

title: Opinion: We Aren’t Built to Live in the Moment
media.description: #NA
description: What best distinguishes human beings from other animals is our foresight, as scientists are just beginning to recognize.
dc.creator: MARTIN E. P. SELIGMAN and JOHN TIERNEY

title: Suspected Cases of Ebola Rise to 29 in Democratic Republic of Congo
media.description: Medical workers treating a patient suspected of having Ebola in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 2007.
media.credit: Ascale Zinten/Doctors Without Borders, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
description: Aid workers are trying to reach a remote part of the country, where there have been three deaths from the virus.
dc.creator: DENISE GRADY

title: The Health Issue: Why Close Encounters With Animals Soothe Us
media.description: Zoie Brogdon, Age 12“I tried soccer, which I hated. I tried track, and there was just mean people. I tried tennis, same thing, mean people. With horses, there still are mean people, but I don’t care. Because I have my horse right next to me.”
media.credit: Ilona Szwarc for The New York Times
description: Compton Jr. Posse in Los Angeles, which brings inner-city children and horses together, reveals the therapeutic power of communing with fellow sentient beings.
dc.creator: Photographs by ILONA SZWARC and TEXT BY CHARLES SIEBERT

title: The Health Issue: The Self-Medicating Animal
media.description: #NA
description: What can we learn from chimps and sheep and maybe even insects that practice medicine on themselves?
dc.creator: MOISES VELASQUEZ-MANOFF

title: The Health Issue: When the Lab Rat Is a Snake
media.description: Burmese python.
media.credit: Robert Clark for The New York Times
description: Why Burmese pythons may be the best way to study diabetes, heart disease and the protective effects of gastric-bypass surgery in humans.
dc.creator: DANIEL ENGBER

title: Wounded Troops Discharged for Misconduct Often Had PTSD or T.B.I.
media.description: An American soldier in an armored vehicle in the village of Darbasiyah, Syria, last month.
description: The Government Accountability Office found that thousands of soldiers were ousted, and cut off from benefits, despite diagnoses of traumatic brain injury or mental disorders.
dc.creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
category.2: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Jerry Canterbury, Whose Paralysis Led to Informed Consent Laws, Is Dead at 78
media.description: Jerry Canterbury with a photograph of J. Edgar Hoover. Mr. Canterbury worked at the F.B.I. as a clerk in the late 1950s.
description: A surgery left Mr. Canterbury partly paralyzed at 19 led to a ruling that transformed how doctors deal with patients in evaluating the risks of treatment.
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: The Health Issue: The Mystery of the Wasting House-Cats
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Mark Peckmezian for The New York Times
description: Forty years ago, feline hyperthyroidism was virtually nonexistent. Now it’s an epidemic — and some scientists think a class of everyday chemicals might be to blame.
dc.creator: EMILY ANTHES

title: The Health Issue: What Animals Taught Me About Being Human
media.description: A family photograph of the writer with house sparrows in 1979.
description: Surrounding myself with animals to feel less alone was a mistake: The greatest comfort is in knowing their lives are not about us at all.
dc.creator: HELEN MACDONALD

title: The Health Issue: The Genetics of Pooched-Out Pooches
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Photo illustration by Catherine Ledner for the New York Times. Prop stylist: Jeanne Kelley.
description: A mutation in some obesity-prone dog breeds might reveal new risk factors for obesity in humans — and perhaps give rise to new drugs.
dc.creator: ROXANNE KHAMSI

title: Under Fire, Climate Scientists Unite With Lawyers to Fight Back
media.description: Lauren Kurtz, executive director of the Climate Science Legal Defense Fund, and Joshua Wolfe, a founder. President Trump’s election has provided a boost to the fund, Mr. Wolfe said.
media.credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
description: Lawyers are building networks to respond to attempts to subvert research and threaten scientists in government and academia.
dc.creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ

title: A Strong Case Against a Pesticide Does Not Faze E.P.A. Under Trump
media.description: Chlorpyrifos is still on the market as an agricultural pesticide, routinely sprayed on common crops like apples, oranges, strawberries and broccoli.
description: For decades, scientists have warned of mounting evidence that exposure to chlorpyrifos may threaten children’s development.
dc.creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

title: Math Champion Wins With Answer About Pecking Chicks
media.description: Luke Robitaille, 13, of Texas, won the Raytheon Mathcounts National Competition on Monday.
description: A 13-year-old boy from Texas took less than a second to answer the word problem in the Raytheon Mathcounts National Competition.
dc.creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

title: When the Immune System Thwarts Lifesaving Drugs
media.description: Magglio Boscarino, who has the genetic disorder Pompe disease, with his mother Becka at home, above, and at school.
media.credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
description: Patients often produce antibodies to the very treatments keeping them alive, sometimes to disastrous effect. The search for solutions is just beginning.
dc.creator: GINA KOLATA

title: Global Health: How a Tsunami in Japan Endangered Children in Cambodia
media.description: Salt producers in Cambodia’s Kampot province. The country’s soils are naturally low in iodine and it has long struggled with iodine deficiency.
description: The catastrophe set off an unexpected shortage of iodine, leaving children in faraway countries vulnerable to cognitive deficits.
dc.creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

title: How Bees Freshen Up
media.description: #NA
description: Research shows how honeybees use their hairy legs to clear pollen from their hairy eyes.
dc.creator: #NA

title: Q&A: Invaders From the New World
media.description: #NA
description: Several animal and plant species native to North America are considered invaders elsewhere, but on the whole North America has more imports than exports.
dc.creator: C. CLAIBORNE RAY

title: What You Need to Know if You Have Breast Implants
media.description: Nearly all the cases of lymphoma have been linked to textured implants like the one shown here.
description: There is no need to remove implants if you have no problems, but if you have swelling, fluid buildup, lumps or asymmetry you should see a doctor.
dc.creator: DENISE GRADY

title: A Shocking Diagnosis: Breast Implants ‘Gave Me Cancer’
media.description: After learning she had breast cancer, Raylene Hollrah of Hermann, Mo., had a double mastectomy. But then cancer struck again — caused by the implants used to rebuild her chest.
media.credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
description: A rare cancer of the immune system, linked to implants, has had devastating effects on women, many of whom had reconstructive surgery after breast cancer.
dc.creator: DENISE GRADY

title: Global Health: Candidate to Lead the W.H.O. Accused of Covering Up Epidemics
media.description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus in 2016. He has been accused of covering up cholera outbreaks by an associate of a rival for World Health Organization director general.
description: As Ethiopia’s health minister, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus ignored cholera outbreaks, a global health expert and adviser to a rival candidate charges.
dc.creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

title: Ancient Burial Chamber Uncovered in Egypt, With 17 Mummies ... So Far
media.description: #NA
description: The remains, which are thought to be more than 1,500 years old, were discovered at a funerary site being excavated by students from Cairo University.
dc.creator: ELI ROSENBERG

title: A Strong Case Against a Pesticide Does Not Faze E.P.A. Under Trump
media.description: Chlorpyrifos is still on the market as an agricultural pesticide, routinely sprayed on common crops like apples, oranges, strawberries and broccoli.
description: For decades, scientists have warned of mounting evidence that exposure to chlorpyrifos may threaten children’s development.
dc.creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

title: In Win for Environmentalists, Senate Keeps an Obama-Era Climate Change Rule
media.description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, broke with his party on Wednesday to help keep a regulation to control the release of methane.
description: Senators voted 51 to 49 to block a measure that would have undone a regulation to control the release of methane from oil and gas wells on public land.
dc.creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

title: E.P.A. Dismisses Members of Major Scientific Review Board
media.description: Scott Pruitt, left, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, with President Trump and a group of coal miners in March as the president signed an executive order that rolled back many climate-change policies.
description: A spokesman for the agency’s administrator said he would consider replacing the academic scientists with representatives from industries the agency is supposed to regulate.
dc.creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

title: By Degrees: A Parable From Down Under for U.S. Climate Scientists
media.description: John Church in Hobart in September 2010. He is known internationally for helping to bring statistical and analytical rigor to longstanding questions about sea level rise.
description: Politics intruded on climate science in Australia. The scientists fought back, led by John Church, a leading world expert on sea level rise.
dc.creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
category.3: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)

title: The New Threat to Wolves in and Around Yellowstone
media.description: A wolf chases magpies and ravens from an elk carcass in Yellowstone National Park in 2016. Since the mid-1990s when 31 wolves were trucked into the park from Canada, their numbers have grown and stabilized.
description: Packs of the animals, once endangered, have flourished, but biologists worry about the effects of renewed hunting outside the national park.
dc.creator: JIM ROBBINS

title: Mass Die-Off of Whales in Atlantic Is Being Investigated
media.description: Workers inspecting a dead humpback whale that washed up on Rockaway Beach in Queens this month.
description: Officials are seeking the reason for an “unusual mortality event” that has left 41 humpback whales dead since early 2016 from North Carolina to Maine.
dc.creator: TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG

title: Trillions of Plastic Bits, Swept Up by Current, Are Littering Arctic Waters
media.description: A photo collage of plastic fragments found in the Arctic Ocean by the research team. A study published Wednesday shows a major ocean current is carrying trillions of bits of plastic from the North Atlantic to the Greenland and Barents seas, and leaving them there.
description: A new study found that a major ocean current is carrying plastic from the North Atlantic to the Greenland and Barents seas, and leaving it there.
dc.creator: TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG

title: Climate Change Reroutes a Yukon River in a Geological Instant
media.description: An aerial view of the ice canyon that now carries meltwater from the Kaskawulsh Glacier, on the right, away from the Slims River. “River piracy” refers to one river capturing and diverting the flow of another.
description: Melting water from one of Canada’s largest glaciers used to flow north, to the Bering Sea. Last spring, it reversed course, a case of what scientists call “river piracy.”
dc.creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ

title: Matter: Antarctic Ice Reveals Earth’s Accelerating Plant Growth
media.description: A boreal forest in Quebec. A new study suggests the world’s plants capture an extra 28 billion tons of carbon each year.
description: Scientists compiling a record of the atmosphere based on air trapped in Antarctic ice found that rising carbon dioxide has accelerated plant growth.
dc.creator: CARL ZIMMER

title: We Might Soon Resurrect Extinct Species. Is It Worth the Cost?
media.description: An illustration of an extinct rat kangaroo, published in 1825. Researchers recently analyzed the costs and benefits of re-establishing and maintaining 16 species in Australia and New Zealand that went extinct in the last millennium.
description: Scientists disagree about whether bringing extinct species back from the dead will result in a net loss of global biodiversity.
dc.creator: STEPH YIN

title: The Health Issue: The Mystery of the Wasting House-Cats
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Mark Peckmezian for The New York Times
description: Forty years ago, feline hyperthyroidism was virtually nonexistent. Now it’s an epidemic — and some scientists think a class of everyday chemicals might be to blame.
dc.creator: EMILY ANTHES

title: The Health Issue: What Animals Taught Me About Being Human
media.description: A family photograph of the writer with house sparrows in 1979.
description: Surrounding myself with animals to feel less alone was a mistake: The greatest comfort is in knowing their lives are not about us at all.
dc.creator: HELEN MACDONALD

title: The Health Issue: The Genetics of Pooched-Out Pooches
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Photo illustration by Catherine Ledner for the New York Times. Prop stylist: Jeanne Kelley.
description: A mutation in some obesity-prone dog breeds might reveal new risk factors for obesity in humans — and perhaps give rise to new drugs.
dc.creator: ROXANNE KHAMSI

title: Global Health: How a Tsunami in Japan Endangered Children in Cambodia
media.description: Salt producers in Cambodia’s Kampot province. The country’s soils are naturally low in iodine and it has long struggled with iodine deficiency.
description: The catastrophe set off an unexpected shortage of iodine, leaving children in faraway countries vulnerable to cognitive deficits.
dc.creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

title: NASA Denies Trump’s Request to Send Astronauts Past the Moon on New Rocket
media.description: The inside of the Space Launch System’s liquid hydrogen tank.
description: The agency announced that adding astronauts to the mission would have cost $600 million to $900 million and required significantly more work and time.
dc.creator: KENNETH CHANG

title: Trilobites: The Harmony That Keeps Trappist-1’s 7 Earth-size Worlds From Colliding
media.description: A visualization of the orbits of the seven planets circling the star Trappist-1.
description: Astronomers can now explain why the recently discovered Earth-size planets, tightly packed, don’t simply fly apart. And now, you can give it a listen.
dc.creator: KENNETH CHANG

title: A Photo From Space Shows Belgium Shining Bright, and Social Media Lights Up
media.description: A photograph taken by the astronaut Thomas Pesquet shows Warsaw at the bottom and Belgium at top left, with the aurora borealis at right. Belgium keeps most of its street lights on all night, even along country roads.
media.credit: Thomas Pesquet/European Space Agency, via NASA
description: Photos taken by a French astronaut sparked a discussion about their beauty — and also raised questions about energy use.
dc.creator: MILAN SCHREUER

title: Out There: Cassini’s Grand Finale: A Dive Between Saturn and Its Rings
media.description: An image from the Cassini spacecraft shows Earth as a point of light between the icy rings of Saturn.
description: The spacecraft is set to venture into the gap between Saturn and its innermost ring 22 times until Sept. 15, then crash into the planet.
dc.creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

title: Plumes From Saturn’s Moon Enceladus Hint That It Could Support Life
media.description: Rows of plumes rise from ice fractures on the surface of Enceladus.
description: Data from the Cassini spacecraft suggest that hydrothermal vents could provide ingredients for microbes or other forms of alien life to exist.
dc.creator: KENNETH CHANG

title: A New Exoplanet May Be Most Promising Yet in Search for Life
media.description: An artist’s impression of the newly discovered rocky exoplanet. The exoplanet is close enough that astronomers are hopeful that with the next generation of big telescopes, they will be able to probe its atmosphere for signs of water or other evidence of suitability for life.
description: The planet, about 40 light years from Earth, is close enough that astronomers hope they will someday be able to probe its atmosphere for signs of water or other evidence of suitability for life.
dc.creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

title: Trilobites: Photos of Jupiter From NASA Spacecraft, Both Near and Far
media.description: The Hubble Space Telescope took this photograph of Jupiter on Monday as part of an annual global survey to look for changes in the storms, winds and clouds.
description: The Juno space probe and the Hubble Space Telescope recorded new images of Jupiter that will help scientists study the solar system’s largest planet.
dc.creator: KENNETH CHANG

title: SpaceX Launches a Satellite With a Partly Used Rocket
media.description: A Falcon 9 rocket after a successful launch at the Kennedy Space Center.
description: The use of a rocket booster that had flown once before may open an era of cheaper space travel, particularly for business ventures like satellite companies.
dc.creator: KENNETH CHANG

title: Flecks of Extraterrestrial Dust, All Over the Roof
media.description: Varieties of space dust, barely the width of a human hair. These photomicrographs were made with a special camera setup that magnifies the dust grains nearly 3,000 times.
description: A jazz musician from Norway hunted bits of cosmic debris for eight years and found it everywhere. Turns out, tons of it land every day.
dc.creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD
category.5: In Search of Stardust: Amazing Micro-Meteorites and Their Terrestrial Imposters (Book)

title: Out There: Cosmos Controversy: The Universe Is Expanding, but How Fast?
media.description: A Hubble Space Telescope image of a group of interacting galaxies called Arp 273.
description: A small discrepancy in the value of a long-sought number has fostered a debate about just how well we know the cosmos.
dc.creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

title: Vera Rubin, 88, Dies; Opened Doors in Astronomy, and for Women
media.description: Vera Rubin in the 1970s, when she mapped the distribution of mass in spiral galaxies by measuring how fast they rotated.
media.credit: Carnegie Institution of Washington, via Associated Press
description: Dr. Rubin, who was awarded the National Medal of Science in 1993, ushered in the cosmic realization that most of the universe is invisible.
dc.creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

title: Trilobites: Spotting Mysterious Twinkles on Earth From a Million Miles Away
media.description: An image from the Dscovr satellite, taken on Dec. 3, 2015, shows a glint over central South America.
description: Hundreds of reflections observed by a satellite are a result of ice crystals floating in clouds at high altitudes, NASA scientists say.
dc.creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

title: The New Old Age: Planning to Age in Place? Find a Contractor Now
media.description: #NA
description: Virtually all single-family homes lack features needed to accommodate aging owners’ limitations. But there are specialists prepared to help fix that.
dc.creator: PAULA SPAN

title: Babies From Skin Cells? Prospect Is Unsettling to Some Experts
media.description: Mice that were created from tail cells. Researchers in Japan made viable eggs from the skin cells of adult female mice, and produced embryos that were implanted into female mice, who then gave birth to healthy babies.
description: Researchers say that scientists may soon be able to create a baby from human skin cells that have been coaxed to grow into eggs and sperm.
dc.creator: TAMAR LEWIN

title: F.D.A. Warns of Faulty Lead Testing in Children and Mothers
media.description: Christina Murphy watched as her 3-year-old daughter, Lilly, reached for a bottle of water to use during bath time at their home in Flint, Mich., where the family avoided using tap water because of concerns about lead.
media.credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
description: The concern is that certain blood tests may have underestimated blood lead levels, providing false reassurance about risk for lead exposure.
dc.creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

title: Ask Well: How Much Weight Do I Need to Lose to Prevent Diabetes?
media.description: #NA
description: Blood tests can determine if you have prediabetes, but losing a small amount of weight can prevent its progression to diabetes.
dc.creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

title: Suspected Cases of Ebola Rise to 29 in Democratic Republic of Congo
media.description: Medical workers treating a patient suspected of having Ebola in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 2007.
media.credit: Ascale Zinten/Doctors Without Borders, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
description: Aid workers are trying to reach a remote part of the country, where there have been three deaths from the virus.
dc.creator: DENISE GRADY

title: Phys Ed: New Advice to Move More After a Concussion
media.description: #NA
media.credit: John McDonnell/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
description: Athletes with concussions are told to give up activity, screens and school for weeks. Now experts think a little more activity helps the brain heal.
dc.creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

title: Traveling Abroad? Get a Measles Shot
media.description: #NA
description: Adult travelers who are not immune to measles risk bringing home a highly contagious and sometimes fatal disease.
dc.creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

title: Yogurt May Be Good for the Bones
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times
description: Older men and women who ate yogurt daily had a lower risk of osteoporosis than those who did not eat yogurt.
dc.creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

title: Well : Of Mice and Mindfulness
media.description: #NA
description: Putting mice into something like a meditative state may shed light on the human brain.
dc.creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

title: Texas House Approves New Limits on Abortion
media.description: #NA
description: State lawmakers backed legislation banning a second-trimester procedure and the sale or donation of fetal tissue. The measure is expected to pass in the State Senate as well.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: UnitedHealth Overbilled Medicare by Billions, U.S. Says in Suit
media.description: Benjamin Poehling, a former finance director for UnitedHealthcare Medicare and Retirement, filed a whistle-blower lawsuit that the Justice Department has joined.
media.credit: Ackerman & Gruber for The New York Times
description: The Justice Department said adjustments to patients’ charts were made to reap greater payments, but the company said it broke no rules.
dc.creator: MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
category.6: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

title: Party Coverage: Scene City: Pretty in Pink
media.description: #NA
description: Galas were held for the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, the New York Philharmonic, El Museo del Barrio, and the National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations.
dc.creator: DENNY LEE

title: Race Spectators Behaving Badly
media.description: Vanderlei de Lima of Brazil is grabbed by a spectator at the 2004 Olympic Marathon event in Athens.
description: Runners and race planners can take steps to rein in spectators. But things still happen.
dc.creator: JEN A. MILLER

title: Duterte Orders Strict Smoking Ban in Philippines, and Asks Citizens to Help
media.description: A fishing boat’s crew heads out from Kalibo, the Philippines. More than a quarter of Filipinos smoke, according to a 2015 World Health Organization report, including 11 percent of minors.
media.credit: Hannah Reyes for The New York Times
description: The executive order, made public on Thursday, banned public smoking and said citizens should band together to help catch and charge violators.
dc.creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

title: Wounded Troops Discharged for Misconduct Often Had PTSD or T.B.I.
media.description: An American soldier in an armored vehicle in the village of Darbasiyah, Syria, last month.
description: The Government Accountability Office found that thousands of soldiers were ousted, and cut off from benefits, despite diagnoses of traumatic brain injury or mental disorders.
dc.creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
category.2: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Jerry Canterbury, Whose Paralysis Led to Informed Consent Laws, Is Dead at 78
media.description: Jerry Canterbury with a photograph of J. Edgar Hoover. Mr. Canterbury worked at the F.B.I. as a clerk in the late 1950s.
description: A surgery left Mr. Canterbury partly paralyzed at 19 led to a ruling that transformed how doctors deal with patients in evaluating the risks of treatment.
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: Steroid Shots Do Little for Knee Pain of Arthritis
media.description: #NA
description: Corticosteroid injections were no more effective than a placebo in relieving pain or stiffness or improving the ability to walk.
dc.creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

title: Texas Seeks Medicaid Money It Gave Up Over Planned Parenthood Ban
media.description: Kristy Anderson testifying as a “Texas woman” in support of Planned Parenthood during a Texas Women’s Health Advisory Committee meeting in Austin on Monday.
media.credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
description: Four years after Texas gave up millions of dollars in federal Medicaid funds, a request presents an important early test for the Trump administration.
dc.creator: ABBY GOODNOUGH

title: A Whistle-Blower Tells of Health Insurers Bilking Medicare
media.description: Benjamin Poehling, a former finance director at UnitedHealth Group, in Minneapolis. He contends that his company and other insurers have been systematically bilking Medicare Advantage for years.
media.credit: Ackerman and Gruber for The New York Times
description: A former executive at UnitedHealth says he was paid bonuses to make patients look sicker than they were, which led to bigger reimbursements.
dc.creator: MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
category.5: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

title: A Strong Case Against a Pesticide Does Not Faze E.P.A. Under Trump
media.description: Chlorpyrifos is still on the market as an agricultural pesticide, routinely sprayed on common crops like apples, oranges, strawberries and broccoli.
description: For decades, scientists have warned of mounting evidence that exposure to chlorpyrifos may threaten children’s development.
dc.creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

title: Red Meat Increases Risk of Dying From 8 Diseases
media.description: #NA
description: High red meat consumption increased the rate of dying from cancer, heart disease, respiratory disease, stroke, diabetes, infections, kidney disease and liver disease.
dc.creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

title: When the Immune System Thwarts Lifesaving Drugs
media.description: Magglio Boscarino, who has the genetic disorder Pompe disease, with his mother Becka at home, above, and at school.
media.credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
description: Patients often produce antibodies to the very treatments keeping them alive, sometimes to disastrous effect. The search for solutions is just beginning.
dc.creator: GINA KOLATA

title: Global Health: How a Tsunami in Japan Endangered Children in Cambodia
media.description: Salt producers in Cambodia’s Kampot province. The country’s soils are naturally low in iodine and it has long struggled with iodine deficiency.
description: The catastrophe set off an unexpected shortage of iodine, leaving children in faraway countries vulnerable to cognitive deficits.
dc.creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

title: Profiles in Science: Brenda Milner, Eminent Brain Scientist, Is ‘Still Nosy’ at 98
media.description: Dr. Brenda Milner in her office at the Montreal Neurological Institute and Hospital last month.
media.credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
description: Seven decades after she began, Dr. Milner continues to explore the biology of memory and how the brain’s many parts function together.
dc.creator: BENEDICT CAREY

title: Personal Health: Strategies to Navigate the Emergency Room
media.description: #NA
description: Complaints often stem from a misunderstanding of how emergency rooms work and how patients themselves can be helpful.
dc.creator: JANE E. BRODY

title: The New Health Care: Why Marathons Are More Dangerous for Nearby Residents Than Runners
media.description: #NA
description: Road closings during races can cause critical delays for patients trying to get to the hospital or waiting for an ambulance.
dc.creator: AARON E. CARROLL

title: Retro Report: Chasing Cures for Deadly Scourges, and Getting in Our Own Way
media.description: #NA
description: Smallpox was eradicated globally four decades ago. That awe-inspiring triumph has long begged to be duplicated. Yet to date, it stands alone.
dc.creator: CLYDE HABERMAN

title: What You Need to Know if You Have Breast Implants
media.description: Nearly all the cases of lymphoma have been linked to textured implants like the one shown here.
description: There is no need to remove implants if you have no problems, but if you have swelling, fluid buildup, lumps or asymmetry you should see a doctor.
dc.creator: DENISE GRADY

title: A Shocking Diagnosis: Breast Implants ‘Gave Me Cancer’
media.description: After learning she had breast cancer, Raylene Hollrah of Hermann, Mo., had a double mastectomy. But then cancer struck again — caused by the implants used to rebuild her chest.
media.credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
description: A rare cancer of the immune system, linked to implants, has had devastating effects on women, many of whom had reconstructive surgery after breast cancer.
dc.creator: DENISE GRADY

title: Global Health: Candidate to Lead the W.H.O. Accused of Covering Up Epidemics
media.description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus in 2016. He has been accused of covering up cholera outbreaks by an associate of a rival for World Health Organization director general.
description: As Ethiopia’s health minister, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus ignored cholera outbreaks, a global health expert and adviser to a rival candidate charges.
dc.creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

title: The New Health Care: The U.S. Is Failing in Infant Mortality, Starting at One Month Old
media.description: #NA
description: The United States does worse than about two dozen other industrialized nations in this crucial measure of public health.
dc.creator: AARON E. CARROLL

title: Many Readers Say No to Idea of Life-Extending Drug, but Yes for Their Dogs
media.description: Rascal underwent tests to see if he was a candidate for a clinical trial to determine whether the drug rapamycin could slow aging. Rascal’s owner, not pictured, wrote that because of the drug, the dog is “happier and friendlier and has more energy.”
description: “You can’t cheat death,” wrote a reader who echoed many responses to an article about drug tests on dogs to try to slow aging. But others said the goal seemed worthy.
dc.creator: NANCY WARTIK

title: The Health Issue: The Improvisational Oncologist
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Illustration by Cristiana Couceiro. Photograph by Ansel Adams, via the National Archives, College Park, Md.
description: In an era of rapidly proliferating, precisely targeted treatments, every cancer case has to be played by ear.
dc.creator: SIDDHARTHA MUKHERJEE

title: The Health Issue: An Old Idea, Revived: Starve Cancer to Death
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Photo illustration by Cristiana Couceiro. Source photograph from Getty Images and Wikimedia Commons.
description: In the early 20th century, the German biochemist Otto Warburg believed that tumors could be treated by disrupting their source of energy. His idea was dismissed for decades — until now.
dc.creator: SAM APPLE

title: The Health Issue: When Do You Give Up on Treating a Child With Cancer?
media.description: Esther Levy follows Andrew in their yard.
media.credit: Lucas Foglia for The New York Times
description: Andrew Levy’s parents knew that the rare and deadly cancer in his blood could not be beaten, so they began to prepare for the worst. Then something mysterious happened.
dc.creator: MELANIE THERNSTROM

title: The Health Issue: Learning From the Lazarus Effect
media.description: Grace Silva at home in Massachusetts.
media.credit: Phyllis Dooney for The New York Times
description: Most clinical trials for cancer drugs are failures. But for a handful of patients, a drug proves to be nearly a cure. What can science learn from these “exceptional responders”?
dc.creator: GARETH COOK

title: The New Health Care: Should You Circumcise Your Baby Boy?
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by Lotus Images, Picsfive/shutterstock
description: Research points to both advantages and disadvantages. In the end, it’s a personal choice.
dc.creator: AARON E. CARROLL

title: The New Health Care: Avoiding Peanuts to Avoid an Allergy Is a Bad Strategy for Most
media.description: #NA
description: New research on potential allergens fits with a wider hypothesis that complete avoidance of risky substances doesn’t work well.
dc.creator: AARON E. CARROLL

title: Aging Runners Find Help for a Question: How Slow Will I Get?
media.description: Runners’ performances start to decline with age. Now they can figure out what to expect.
description: Thanks to Ray Fair, a professor in the economics department at Yale, runners have an exact schedule that will predict how their performance will decline as they age.
dc.creator: GINA KOLATA

title: The New Health Care: A Study on Fats That Doesn’t Fit the Story Line
media.description: So which kind of fat is actually bad for you?
media.credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
description: Old but only recently published research increases a concern that when it comes to nutrition, personal beliefs can trump science.
dc.creator: AARON E. CARROLL

title: Sean Parker, a Facebook and Napster Pioneer, to Start Cancer Immunotherapy Effort
media.description: Sean Parker is donating $250 million to start the Parker Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy, an effort that he said represented a new “blueprint for biomedical research funding.”
description: Mr. Parker’s institute will try to spur collaboration among six academic centers in developing ways to unleash patients’ immune systems to fight cancer.
dc.creator: ANDREW POLLACK
category.9: University of Texas M D Anderson Cancer Center

title: Well: Direct-to-Consumer Lab Tests, No Doctor Visit Required
media.description: #NA
description: Firms promise to help consumers spot metabolic red flags. Critics say the services persuade healthy people to seek unneeded treatment.
dc.creator: ANAHAD O'CONNOR

title: Well: A Doctor on Schedule, Rarely on Time
media.description: #NA
description: Everyone can tell when I’m behind. Every visit is pared to essentials. Paperwork is postponed, chatting minimized.
dc.creator: ABIGAIL ZUGER, M.D.

title: Well: Early Puberty in Girls Raises the Risk of Depression
media.description: #NA
description: Those who developed breasts younger than their peers had a higher risk of depression, a new study found.
dc.creator: PERRI KLASS, M.D.

title: Well: War Wounds That Time Alone Can’t Heal
media.description: The new documentary “Almost Sunrise” follows Tom Voss and Anthony Anderson, two troubled Iraq war veterans, walking from Milwaukee to Los Angeles.
description: Moral injury resembles post-traumatic stress disorder with an added burden of guilt, and requires different treatment.
dc.creator: JANE E. BRODY

title: Well: Think Like a Doctor: The Tired Gardener Solved!
media.description: #NA
description: Readers solve the case of a previously healthy 67-year-old gardener who is too exhausted and feverish to garden.
dc.creator: LISA SANDERS, M.D.

title: Personal Health: Parenting Advice From ‘America’s Worst Mom’
media.description: #NA
description: A New York City mother embraces her leading role in a campaign to return to the days when children played and navigated through life without constant adult supervision.
dc.creator: JANE E. BRODY

title: Ask Well: Is Rebounding Good Exercise?
media.description: #NA
description: A reader asks: Does rebounding, or a mini-trampoline, provide the miracle benefits that its advocates say it does?
dc.creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

title: Genetic Gamble : In Gene Sequencing Treatment for Leukemia, Glimpses of the Future
media.description: Dr. Lukas Wartman, a leukemia patient in remission, being examined by his doctor, John DiPersio, in January in St. Louis.
media.credit: Dilip Vishwanat for The New York Times
description: A novel method known as whole genome sequencing focuses on genes that drive a cancer, not the tissues or organ where it originates.
dc.creator: GINA KOLATA

title: Global Update: After Measles Success, Rwanda to Get Rubella Vaccine
media.description: #NA
description: Encouraged by Rwanda’s steady gains in curbing measles, donors are paying for a more expensive dual vaccine that will target rubella, too.
dc.creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

title: Global Update: New Polio Strains That Protect Vaccine Factory Workers
media.description: #NA
description: The strains have the same ability to invoke an immune reaction as the live viruses now used to make vaccine do, but with no risk to vaccine factory employees.
dc.creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

title: The New Health Care: Sorry, There’s Nothing Magical About Breakfast
media.description: Our belief in the power of breakfast is based on misinterpreted research and poor studies.
description: Don’t feel bad if you’d rather skip it. Studies have not proved its importance.
dc.creator: AARON E. CARROLL

title: Public Health: You’d Be Surprised at How Many Foods Contain Added Sugar
media.description: Some pasta sauces have high amounts of added sugar.
description: Because of an F.D.A. labeling change, many consumers will learn that added sugars are in many products generally thought to be healthy.
dc.creator: MARGOT SANGER-KATZ

title: Scaling Back: A New Policy Disagreement Between Clinton and Sanders: Soda Taxes
media.description: Jim Kenney, mayor of Philadelphia, at a roundtable with Hillary Clinton and others in Philadelphia this month. Mr. Kenney has emphasized the soda tax as a way of funding education.
media.credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
description: Is a tax on sugar-sweetened beverages an admirable way to improve public health, or a regressive measure that hurts the poor? The left is divided.

media.description: #NA

title: The Future Issue: You, Only Better
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Photo illustration by Andrew B. Myers. Prop styling by Sonia Rentsch.
description: Is “biohacking” just a fad? Or can data-driven diets help us become an improved, happier species?
