description: When man’s best friend gets too fat, that pet becomes a potential fitness aid for its owner.

title: Well: Why High-Impact Exercise Is Good for Your Bones

title: Affordable Care Act Repeal Is Back on the Agenda, Republicans Say
media.description: Stephen K. Bannon, one of President Trump’s chief advisers, left a meeting at the Capitol last week during negotiations on the American Health Care Act.
media.credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
description: Under extreme pressure from conservative activists, House Republican leaders and the White House say they have restarted negotiations.

title: 2018 Dilemma for Republicans: Which Way Now on Obamacare?
media.description: “Repeal Obamacare” buttons at a Heritage Foundation booth during the Conservative Political Action Conference last month in National Harbor, Md.
media.credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
description: Caught between alienating their conservative base and angering a broader group of voters, Republicans risk losing their House majority.

category.1: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: In Health Bill’s Defeat, Medicaid Comes of Age
media.description: President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the bill creating Medicare and Medicaid in 1965, with former President Harry S. Truman, who had tried to establish national health insurance, seated at right.
description: Medicaid now covers more Americans than Medicare, and it played a major role in stopping the Republican drive to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.
dc.creator: KATE ZERNIKE, ABBY GOODNOUGH and PAM BELLUCK
category.1: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: Public Health: Trump’s Choice on Obamacare: Sabotage or Co-opt?
media.description: Supporters of the Affordable Care Act outside the White House on Tuesday. President Trump said the health law is “exploding now.”
description: President Trump and congressional Republicans must decide quickly whether to make the law work or try to undermine it.
dc.creator: MARGOT SANGER-KATZ
category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: In Major Defeat for Trump, Push to Repeal Health Law Fails
media.description: House Speaker Paul D. Ryan walked in the Capitol on Friday after a vote on the rules for debating the American Health Care Act, the bill to replace the Affordable Care Act known as Obamacare.
media.credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
description: House Republican leaders withdrew legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act from the House floor before it could be defeated, a loss for President Trump.
dc.creator: ROBERT PEAR, THOMAS KAPLAN and MAGGIE HABERMAN
category.3: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: Economic View: What Comes Next for Obamacare? The Case for Medicare for All
media.description: Paul Ryan, the House Speaker, at a news conference this month. His bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act has drawn criticism from the right and the left.
media.credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
description: The pains of losing the Affordable Care Act would generate a gigantic backlash. But universal access to Medicare would change that.
dc.creator: ROBERT H. FRANK
category.2: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: Trump Tells G.O.P. It’s Now or Never, Demanding House Vote on Health Bill
media.description: Representatives Jim Jordan of Ohio and Raúl R. Labrador of Idaho, members of the House Freedom Caucus, discussed the American Health Care Act on Thursday.
description: President Trump told his party to fall in line behind a health insurance overhaul, and demanded a Friday vote on a bill that appeared to lack a majority to pass.
dc.creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS, ROBERT PEAR and THOMAS KAPLAN
category.5: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: Public Health: Late G.O.P. Proposal Could Mean Plans That Cover Aromatherapy but Not Chemotherapy
media.description: Essential oils at an aromatherapy bar.
media.credit: Gordon M. Grant for The New York Times
description: A problem with stripping away minimum benefit rules is that the whole idea of “health insurance” starts to become murky.
dc.creator: MARGOT SANGER-KATZ
category.2: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: Leaders Struggle to Unite House Republicans Behind Health Bill
media.description: Representative Jim Jordan of the House Freedom Caucus. More than 25 of its members were said to oppose the bill.
description: With the chamber set to vote on Thursday, conservatives said a Republican measure to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act still lacked support.
dc.creator: ROBERT PEAR and THOMAS KAPLAN
category.3: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: As Rivals Stand Silent, One Health Insurer Protests G.O.P. Plan
media.description: Dr. J. Mario Molina, chief executive of Molina Healthcare, with a portrait of his father, who founded the company. Dr. Molina has publicly criticized the House health care bill, which he says could strip away coverage for millions of clients and cause turmoil for the insurance industry.
media.credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
description: Dr. J. Mario Molina, one of the few insurance executives to criticize the House bill publicly, says it could harm insurers and patients alike.
dc.creator: REED ABELSON
category.4: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

title: Public Health: Is the G.O.P. Better Off Politically if the Health Bill Doesn’t Pass?
media.description: Representative Jim Jordan, a member of the House Freedom Caucus, before a television interview this week about the Republican health care plan.
description: Passing the plan could endanger President Trump’s hold on white-working class voters in areas like the Rust Belt.
dc.creator: NATE COHN and MARGOT SANGER-KATZ

title: Ed Talk: Angela Duckworth on Passion, Grit and Success
media.description: #NA
description: The MacArthur “genius” answers questions on the power of resilience.

title: Well: Direct-to-Consumer Lab Tests, No Doctor Visit Required
media.description: #NA
description: Firms promise to help consumers spot metabolic red flags. Critics say the services persuade healthy people to seek unneeded treatment.

title: Well: A Doctor on Schedule, Rarely on Time
media.description: #NA

media.description: #NA
description: Those who developed breasts younger than their peers had a higher risk of depression, a new study found.

title: Well: Think Like a Doctor: The Tired Gardener Solved!

title: Personal Health: Parenting Advice From ‘America’s Worst Mom’
media.description: #NA

title: Ask Well: Is Rebounding Good Exercise?

media.description: #NA

title: How ‘Twin Peaks’ Got Lost, and Found Its Way Back

title: An Appraisal: Chris Cornell: A Spectacular Voice of Grunge, With a Glint of Tragedy

title: A Defense of ‘Transracial’ Identity Roils Philosophy World

title: L.A. Reincarnation: New Art Spaces in Vintage Settings

title: Here Is Your Fall 2017 TV Schedule

description: With “An Ode To,” Solange reimagined “A Seat at the Table” with her own choreography and reconstructed musical arrangements.
dc.creator: SIOBHAN BURKE

title: So, How Did I Do?: From a ‘Super Bunhead’ to a Lead Dancer
media.description: Christine Shevchenko of American Ballet Theater, about to make her debut as Kitri in “Don Quixote,” at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday.
media.credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
description: Christine Shevchenko just danced her first lead in a full-length ballet: Kitri in “Don Quixote.” She dropped her fan but soldiered on. Here’s how it went.
dc.creator: GIA KOURLAS

title: On the Frivolities of Ballet, the Contradictory Art
media.description: A scene from “Whipped Cream,” a new ballet by Alexei Ratmansky.
description: American Ballet Theater’s season reminds us that ballet can turn silliness into enchantment but also turn serious themes into silliness.
dc.creator: ALASTAIR MACAULAY

title: Critic's Notebook: No More Gang Rape Scenes in Ballets, Please
media.description: Sterling Hyltin, thrown into the air by male dancers in a scene of violence on the opening night of “Odessa,” at New York City Ballet.
description: Violence against women is pervasive in contemporary works of ballet. Enough is enough: It’s time to give women as much power and agency as men.
dc.creator: SIOBHAN BURKE

title: An Adventurous First Season for Skirball Center’s New Director
media.description: Jay Wegman, at the Abrons Arts Center. He gave up his post as artistic director there to lead N.Y.U.’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, where his first season will include an immersive “Pirates of Penzance” and a John Zorn marathon.
media.credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
description: Jay Wegman, who left the Abrons Arts Center to lead Skirball last year, has unveiled an ambitious first season.

title: DanceAfrica at BAM Explores a Diaspora’s Traditions
media.description: The BAM/Restoration Dance Youth Ensemble in 2016.

title: Mark Ryden’s Stage Confections at Paul Kasmin Gallery
media.description: Mark Ryden’s “Nicolo,” on display at the Paul Kasmin Gallery.

title: ‘The Red Shoes’ and ‘Brigadoon’: City Center’s New Season
media.description: Ashley Shaw in Matthew Bourne’s ballet “The Red Shoes,” which will have its American premiere this fall at City Center.

title: What Is a Dance Doing in the Middle of Enda Walsh’s Play?

title: 10 Spring and Summer Dance Festivals
media.description: The Hungarian performance artist Eszter Salamon’s “Monument 0.”

title: #SpeakingInDance: Snapping, Gliding and Bone-Breaking: The World of Flexing
media.description: #NA

title: Reviews: Summoning Spirits and Dancing in Latex Body Bags
media.description: Koma performing his solo work “The Ghost Festival” at St. Mark’s Church.

title: Shelby Shellz Suzie Q Felton, the ‘Lady Professor’ of Flexing
media.description: Shelby Shellz Suzie Q Felton rehearsing for “Flexn Evolution,” which opens on Thursday at the Park Avenue Armory in New York City.

title: Ayodele Casel, Tap Storyteller, Lets Her Feet Do the Talking
media.description: Ayodele Casel, an actress, choreographer and dancer, was last in the spotlight in October, when she tapped not to music but to a recording of her own words at a “Broadway for Hillary” fund-raiser.

title: Review: ‘She’ Brings Stories of Sexual Violence to the Stage
media.description: Jinah Parker in “She.”

title: Erasing Stravinsky and Rethinking ‘The Nutcracker’: N.Y.U. Announces Ballet Fellowships

title: Chuck Davis, Who Brought African Dance Traditions to America, Dies at 80
media.description: Chuck Davis in 2007. Far left, a DanceAfrica performance in 2015 featuring members of Bale Folclórico da Bahia, a Brazilian folkloric dance company. Left, the Zimbabwe troupe Umkhathi Theater Works at DanceAfrica in 2013.

title: Review: Justin Peck’s ‘Decalogue’ Pushes Into New Ballet Forms
media.description: Gonzalo Garcia, center, with, from left, Sara Mearns, Kristen Segin and Claire Kretzschmar of New York City Ballet performing in “The Decalogue” on Friday at the David H. Koch Theater of Lincoln Center.

title: Review: At Pennsylvania Ballet, Lots of Pillows and Pas de Deux

title: Misty Copeland, a Ballerina With Real Acting Chops
media.description: As Misty Copeland gets older, she seeks even more depth in her acting.

title: Critic's Notebook: Cannes Rolls Out the Red Carpet (Now With Metal Detectors)
media.description: Marion Cotillard, left, and Charlotte Gainsbourg in Arnaud Desplechin’s feature “Ismael’s Ghosts,” in competition at this year’s Cannes Film Festival.

title: Review: ‘Alien: Covenant’ Stays on Brand With Its Terror

media.description: From left, Olivia Olson, Liam Neeson and Thomas Brodie-Sangster in “Red Nose Day Actually.”

title: Elinor Bunin Munroe, Film and TV Graphic Designer With a Theater in Her Name, Dies

title: Women Face Long Odds at U.S. Film Festivals, Study Finds

title: Oleg Vidov, the ‘Soviet Robert Redford,’ Dies at 73
media.description: Oleg Vidov in the popular 1972 film “The Headless Horseman.” With his chiseled good looks, Mr. Vidov was a box office draw.

title: Why the Netflix-Cannes Clash Couldn’t Be Avoided
media.description: A scene from “Okja,” one of two Netflix films in competition at this year’s Cannes Film Festival.

title: Jimmy Kimmel Will Return as Oscars Host

title: Square Feet: Bethesda Readies for a Major Remake
media.description: The Metro station in the heart of the central business district in Bethesda, Md. The community is about to undergo a makeover.
media.credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times
description: Plans include Marriott International moving its headquarters from the suburbs to downtown.
dc.creator: MIRANDA S. SPIVACK

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
media.description: An 8,000-square-foot retail co-op is for sale in this 12-story, mixed-use building at 15 East 16th Street in Manhattan.
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
dc.creator: ROSALIE R. RADOMSKY

title: A Hamptons Hotel Taps Into Rhode Island’s Beach Scene
media.description: George Filopoulos, the founding principal of Metrovest Equities, in a gutted restaurant space last week at Gurney’s Newport Resort and Marina, formerly a Hyatt Regency hotel, on Goat Island, between Newport Harbor and Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island.
media.credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
description: The owners of Gurney’s Montauk, a luxury resort on the tip of Long Island, N.Y., are hoping to replicate their success in the seaside city of Newport.
dc.creator: LISA PREVOST

media.description: 60 Fulton Street

title: Square Feet: Amid Delays, Hong Kong’s Ambitious Museum Plan Takes Shape
media.description: Hong Kong is in the midst of constructing an ambitious cultural district, which will include an Art Park.
media.credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
description: The government is heavily promoting the M+ museum, set to open two years behind schedule in 2019, but questions of curatorial independence remain.
dc.creator: KATHY CHIN LEONG

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
media.description: #NA
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.

title: Square Feet: ‘A Different Los Angeles’: The City Moves to Alter Its Sprawling Image
media.description: Opponents of Measure S, which would have curtailed construction in Los Angeles for two years, during an event in February. The measure was defeated last month.
media.credit: Carlos Gonzalez for The New York Times
description: After voters defeated a measure that would have curtailed construction, the city’s future looks much denser.
dc.creator: LAUREN HERSTIK

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
media.description: #NA
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.

title: Square Feet: Downtown Brooklyn’s Dearth of Office Space Beckons Tishman Speyer
media.description: Workers doing demolition and construction work on the seventh floor of 422 Fulton Street in Brooklyn. Tishman Speyer aims to expand the “world-class office space” available in the borough.
media.credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
description: The developer, which owns Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building, is building a 620,000-square foot office tower.
dc.creator: JULIE SATOW

title: Stores Take Flight From Fifth Avenue in Manhattan
media.description: A window display at Ralph Lauren’s flagship Polo store on Fifth Avenue and 55th Street. The company announced on Tuesday that it would close the location.
media.credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
description: Companies are finding it harder to justify the cavernous spaces and sky-high rents along the shopping strip, as tourism slows and online shopping speeds up.
dc.creator: RACHEL ABRAMS

title: Fiat Chrysler to Modify 100,000 Vehicles After Accusations of Emissions Cheating
media.description: Fiat Chrysler cars at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit in January.
media.credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
description: The company said it would issue a software update for the vehicles as part of efforts to reach a settlement with United States regulators.
dc.creator: JACK EWING

title: Driven: Video Review: A Quieter and More Refined Mazda CX-5
media.description: #NA
description: Car buyers crave style, handling and reliability, all of which Mazda delivers in the redesigned crossover.
dc.creator: TOM VOELK

title: Wheels: First Came the Hydrogen Cars. Now, the Refilling Stations.
media.description: Heather McLaughlin, who in February leased a 2017 Honda Clarity FC, refueling her car at a hydrogen station in Hayward, Calif. The state has 30 hydrogen stations and intends to have 100 by 2020.
media.credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
description: California has 30 hydrogen refilling stations, and automakers are poised to add stations in the Northeast, from New York to Boston.
dc.creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

title: $553 Million Accord for U.S. Drivers Over Takata Airbags
media.description: Cars that were traded in during the Takata recall in a car lot in West Palm Beach, Fla., in January.
media.credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
description: The deal by Toyota, BMW, Subaru and Honda would settle a class-action lawsuit over losses from a recall to repair a deadly defect.
dc.creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

title: Mercedes-Benz Brings a New Model (of Battery) to U.S. Homes
media.description: Mercedes-Benz Energy and Vivint Solar have announced a partnership to bring energy storage units to the United States residential solar market.
description: In a partnership with Vivint Solar, the automaker will market a storage device that can help power lights, appliances — and even electric cars.
dc.creator: DIANE CARDWELL

title: Uber Threatens to Fire Star Engineer in Legal Battle Over Driverless Cars
media.description: A self-driving Uber car in Pittsburgh last year. Uber has been accused by Waymo of conspiring with a former Google engineer to steal trade secrets from Google.
description: The company’s top lawyer ordered Anthony Levandowski to comply in a lawsuit brought by Waymo, a self-driving car business, or face “adverse employment action.”
dc.creator: MIKE ISAAC

title: Ford Moves to Trim Its Ranks as Its Chief Faces a Test
media.description: Mark Fields, the Ford chief executive, at the New York International Auto Show last month.
description: With Mark Fields under investor pressure, the automaker is shedding 1,400 salaried jobs in a step to balance cutbacks with technology investments.
dc.creator: BILL VLASIC and NEAL E. BOUDETTE

title: VW Engineers Wanted O.K. From the Top for Emissions Fraud, Documents Show
media.description: Matthias Müller, the chief executive of Volkswagen, in Hanover, Germany, this month.
description: The documents, along with the continuing criminal investigations in the United States and Germany, signal that the scandal is creeping closer to Volkswagen’s boardroom.
dc.creator: JACK EWING

title: How Uber and Waymo Ended Up Rivals in the Race for Driverless Cars
media.description: Uber employees testing a self-driving Ford Fusion in Pittsburgh last year.
description: Google was an early ally of Uber when it was a ride-hailing start-up. That relationship changed when both pursued self-driving technology in earnest.
dc.creator: MIKE ISAAC

title: Hyundai Whistle-Blower, in Rarity for South Korea, Prompts Recall
media.description: Kim Gwang-ho, an automotive engineer, in Yongin, South Korea, last month. Mr. Kim was the source of internal Hyundai documents that prompted the government to order a recall.
description: A victory for a worker who accused the automaker of hiding defects could help efforts to extend protections for insiders claiming problems or wrongdoing.
dc.creator: JEYUP S. KWAAK

title: Lyft and Waymo Reach Deal to Collaborate on Self-Driving Cars
media.description: Waymo’s self-driving minivan in Detroit at the North American International Auto Show in January.
media.credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
description: The fiercely competitive autonomous vehicle market got a jolt when Lyft, the ride-hailing start-up, and Waymo, the self-driving unit of Google’s parent company, confirmed a partnership.
dc.creator: MIKE ISAAC

title: Uber Engineer Barred From Work on Key Self-Driving Technology, Judge Says
media.description: Anthony Levandowski in 2016. Waymo filed a lawsuit against Uber, accusing it of stealing trade secrets to develop self-driving cars, and Waymo said the thief was Mr. Levandowski.
description: Uber sidestepped a full shutdown of its self-driving car efforts when a judge stopped short of issuing a temporary injunction against the company’s autonomous vehicle program.
dc.creator: MIKE ISAAC

title: Wheels: Discounted Cars Benefit Buyers, but May Spell Trouble for Industry
media.description: Wes Lutz, owner of Extreme Dodge in Jackson, Mich., said steep discounts of new cars were a reaction to a slowing market and increased inventories.
media.credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
description: Hefty price cuts are the latest signs of difficulty in the auto industry, which faces declining sales.
dc.creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

title: A Robot Revolution, This Time in China
media.description: The Ford plant in Hangzhou.
media.credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
description: Car manufacturing in China, once labor-intensive, is now heavily automated.
dc.creator: KEITH BRADSHER

title: As Ford Takes Investor Meeting Online, Brickbats Still Sting
media.description: #NA
description: The automaker came under fire from shareholders over its stock price, its leadership and even the format of the event itself.
dc.creator: BILL VLASIC

title: Driven: Video Review: A Competition Puts S.U.V.s Through Their Paces
media.description: The competition is tough — and also a little sloppy — at the Outdoor Activity Vehicle of the Year competition, also known as Mudfest.
media.credit: Josh Mackey/Northwest Automotive Press AssociationPress Association
description: S.U.V.s can now be pumped with performance or stuffed with luxury. Auto reviewers gather each year to find the best.
dc.creator: TOM VOELK
category.2: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

title: Wheels: 2017 Could Prove to Be a Turning Point for Plug-In Hybrids
media.description: A prototype of Kia’s new Niro plug-in hybrid, which has a starting price of about $23,000.
media.credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
description: New models may help ease consumers’ fears of running out of power before they reach the charging station.
dc.creator: JOHN R. QUAIN
category.4: Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp

title: Wheels: Shortage of Auto Mechanics Has Dealerships Taking Action
media.description: BMW’s technician training center in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. The shortage of technicians is so acute that BMW began its own recruiting program.
media.credit: Fred R. Conrad for The New York Times
description: Car companies have had to create special training and hiring programs to meet the need, and the jobs that are available can pay handsomely.
dc.creator: NORMAN MAYERSOHN

title: Haven’t Bought a Car in a While? It’s a New World Out There
media.description: #NA
description: With people keeping their vehicles longer, a visit to the dealership may leave some feeling like Rip Van Winkle.
dc.creator: TOM VOELK

title: Review: Cars and Culture Clashes in ‘Lowriders’
media.description: Gabriel Chavarria, left, and Theo Rossi, playing vastly different brothers in “Lowriders.”
description: A father is immersed in the lowrider world, while a son wants only to pursue his art. And then another son is released from prison.
dc.creator: NEIL GENZLINGER

title: Wheels: Soon, Your Car May Be Able to Read Your Expressions
media.description: Matt Dunford, exterior designer, with the Fiat Chrysler Portal concept car in January at the Consumer Electronics Association’s annual show.
media.credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
description: Facial recognition and other technology are set to further personalize the driving experience.
dc.creator: JOHN R. QUAIN

title: Neighborhood Joint: Custom Motorcycles, Made Indian Larry’s Way
media.description: A custom-made bike at Indian Larry Motorcycles in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. For those who cannot afford the motorcycles, which start at $65,000, the shop also sells T-shirts, hats and gear.
media.credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
description: The Brooklyn shop sells about eight built-from-scratch bikes a year and counts Ewan McGregor and Brad Pitt among its clientele.
dc.creator: LISA M. COLLINS

title: No Longer a Dream: Silicon Valley Takes On the Flying Car
media.description: The Kitty Hawk Flyer is one of several prototypes being designed by Kitty Hawk, a start-up based in Mountain View, Calif.
description: This isn’t science fiction. A number of start-ups as well as big aerospace firms are trying to build personal aircraft you could fly around town.
dc.creator: JOHN MARKOFF

title: Bigger, Faster, More Lavish: Americans Crave S.U.V.s, and Carmakers Oblige
media.description: Ford’s latest Lincoln Navigator is larger and more powerful than its predecessor, while aiming squarely at car owners seeking luxury features.
media.credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
description: At the New York International Auto Show, powerful sport utility vehicles are at center stage, a sign of the continuing shift away from traditional passenger cars.
dc.creator: BILL VLASIC
category.1: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

title: Ask The Wirecutter: Reasons Not to Dismiss GPS Devices for Your Car
media.description: Rik Paul, the autos editor at The Wirecutter, testing GPS systems on the road. One big advantage a car GPS unit has over phone apps: It doesn’t need a data connection to plot a route.
media.credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
description: While apps like Google Maps provide accurate traffic information, dedicated car-GPS devices do have some advantages.
dc.creator: DAMON DARLIN

title: Wheels: As Auto Prices Rise, Used Cars Are Looking Shinier
media.description: Emily Hurwitz, 28, an advertising executive who lives in San Francisco, with her 2012 Volkswagen Tiguan, which was recently purchased through Shift, a used-car online retailer.
media.credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
description: With new vehicles averaging $34,000, sometimes a model just a few years older can offer considerable savings — if you don’t mind slightly older technology.
dc.creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

title: Stanley Greene, Teller of Uncomfortable Truths, Dies at 68
media.description: Stanley Greene.
description: Mr. Greene was a founding member of Noor Images who covered global conflicts with unblinking honesty.
dc.creator: JAMES ESTRIN

title: William Brohn, Who Made Broadway Orchestras Sing, Dies at 84
media.description: The theater orchestrator William Brohn in 2010.
description: “The central focus for you is to help the composer say what he wants to say,” Mr. Brohn said of his work as an orchestrator.
dc.creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

title: Roger Ailes, Who Built Fox News Into an Empire, Dies at 77
media.description: Roger E. Ailes in 2001. Mr. Ailes was a dominant, often intimidating force in American conservative politics at the helm of Fox News.
description: Mr. Ailes exerted wide influence on American politics with his conservative Fox News, only to be undone by sexual harassment allegations.
dc.creator: CLYDE HABERMAN

title: Chris Cornell, Soundgarden and Audioslave Frontman, Dies at 52
media.description: Chris Cornell during a Soundgarden reunion concert in Newark in 2011.
media.credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
description: The musician’s death in Detroit was “sudden and unexpected,” his representative said in a statement. The medical examiner’s office said the cause of death was suicide.
dc.creator: CARYN GANZ and JOHN LELAND

title: Anne R. Dick, Memoirist and Writer’s Muse, Is Dead at 90
media.description: Anne R. Dick at her home in California in 2010.
media.credit: Craig Lee for The New York Times
description: Her second husband, Philip K. Dick, used their marriage and her persona in books like “The Man in the High Castle” and “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?”
dc.creator: DAVID STREITFELD

title: Beatrice Trum Hunter, ‘Natural Foods Cookbook’ Author, Dies at 98
media.description: Beatrice Trum Hunter’s passion for health was inspired in high school by a book that described American consumers as unwitting guinea pigs for the food, pharmaceutical and cosmetics industries.
description: Mrs. Hunter’s book, her first of 38, was heralded as the nation’s first healthful natural foods cookbook.
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: David Levin, the Only Triple Crown Balloonist, Dies at 68
media.description: David Levin in 2005 at a race in Albuquerque. In 1992 he became the only pilot to capture world championships in hot-air and gas balloons.
description: Mr. Levin, who passed up a law career, won ballooning’s three top events: the hot-air and gas balloon world championships, and the Gordon Bennett Cup.
dc.creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

title: Jeanne Button, Designer of Whimsical Costumes, Dies at 86
media.description: The costume designer Jeanne Button. She compiled the multivolume “A History of Costume in Slides, Notes, and Commentaries,” a 450-page text accompanied by sketches and 1,500 color photographs by her former husband.
description: Ms. Button helped define hundreds of characters in Broadway and Off Broadway plays.
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: Elinor Bunin Munroe, Film and TV Graphic Designer With a Theater in Her Name, Dies
media.description: Elinor Bunin Munroe, with her husband, George B. Munroe, at the ribbon-cutting of the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center in 2011.
description: Known for the film complex at Lincoln Center that bears her name, Ms. Munroe was an Emmy-winning graphic designer whose movie work included “The Producers.”
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: An Appraisal: Chris Cornell: A Spectacular Voice of Grunge, With a Glint of Tragedy
media.description: Chris Cornell in 2015. As a frontman for Soundgarden and Audioslave, he used his formidable vocal talents to question rather than exult.
description: Mr. Cornell’s power as a vocalist lay in his ability to sustain hard-rock melodies while lending more modest ballads an existential gravity.
dc.creator: JON PARELES

title: A Sampling of ‘Natural Foods Cookbook’ Recipes
media.description: #NA
description: The author, Beatrice Trum Hunter, who died at 98, credited the natural ingredients she used for helping her live longer than people who relied on processed foods.
dc.creator: Compiled by AMISHA PADNANI

title: Lloyd Cotsen, Collector of the Ordinary and the Odd, Dies at 88
media.description: Lloyd Cotsen at Neutrogena in 1988. He became chairman of the company, which his father-in-law Emanuel Stolaroff had founded as Natone, and sold it to Johnson & Johnson in 1994.
description: Mr. Cotsen, who sold Neutrogena for $924 million, amassed diverse treasures like children’s books or bamboo baskets in finding “the extraordinary in the ordinary.”
dc.creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

title: Jean Fritz, Who Wrote History Books for Children, Dies at 101
media.description: Jean Fritz in a photograph from 1990.
description: Her works were full of human narratives and quirks, backed by engaging prose and deep archival research.
dc.creator: MARGALIT FOX

title: Frank Brian, Standout in N.B.A.’s Early Years, Dies at 94
media.description: Frank Brian in 1950. He was twice an All-Star in the N.B.A.
media.credit: NBA Photo Library, via Getty Images
description: Slight by current N.B.A. standards at 6 feet 1 inches and about 175 pounds, Mr. Brian was known as a versatile guard at L.S.U. and as a professional.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: The Moors Murders: A Notorious Couple and Their Young Prey
media.description: A search party looking for the victims of Ian Brady and Myra Hindley on Saddleworth Moor in northwestern England in October 1965.
description: Here are the details of the case, how Ian Brady and Myra Hindley were caught, and who their victims were.
dc.creator: AMISHA PADNANI

title: Lee Hall, Artist and de Kooning Biographer, Dies at 82
media.description: Lee Hall in her studio in Massachusetts in 2013.
description: Ms. Hall was an abstract landscape painter who also served as president of the Rhode Island School of Design during a difficult period there.
dc.creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

title: Thomas A. Bolan, Understated Force in New York Law, Dies at 92
media.description: Thomas A. Bolan, far left, and Roy M. Cohn, center, in 1964. Mr. Bolan was a Republican and a founder of the Conservative Party in New York.
description: Mr. Bolan was, next to Roy M. Cohn, the quieter half of an odd couple at a potent law firm and a major player in Republican politics in New York.
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: Oleg Vidov, the ‘Soviet Robert Redford,’ Dies at 73
media.description: Oleg Vidov in the popular 1972 film “The Headless Horseman.” With his chiseled good looks, Mr. Vidov was a box office draw.
description: Mr. Vidov, who starred in several popular films in the Soviet Union before orchestrating an escape to the U.S., went on to have a long Hollywood career.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Jerry Canterbury, Whose Paralysis Led to Informed Consent Laws, Is Dead at 78
media.description: Jerry Canterbury with a photograph of J. Edgar Hoover. Mr. Canterbury worked at the F.B.I. as a clerk in the late 1950s.
description: A surgery left Mr. Canterbury partly paralyzed at 19 led to a ruling that transformed how doctors deal with patients in evaluating the risks of treatment.
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: Ian Brady, Unrepentant Killer of British Children, Dies at 79
media.description: Ian Brady in police custody.
description: Mr. Brady and his lover, Myra Hindley, were known as the Moors Murderers. He tortured and killed children, then buried them in a remote area.
dc.creator: ALAN COWELL

title: Brad Grey, Former Chairman of Paramount Pictures, Dies at 59
media.description: Brad Grey, who was chief executive of Paramount Pictures from 2005 until earlier this year, at the Paramount lot in Hollywood in 2009.
media.credit: Jamie Rector for The New York Times
description: Mr. Grey, who played a pivotal role in the creation of television hits like “The Sopranos,” helped blend the art of talent management with TV and film production.
dc.creator: BROOKS BARNES

title: Thomas V. Daily, Bishop With Legacy Tarnished by Response to Abuse, Dies at 89
media.description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily in 2002. In his 13 years overseeing the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, he forgave more than $100 million in parish debts, raised $67 million in a capital campaign and consolidated parishes.
description: Bishop Daily raised tens of millions of dollars to repair schools and churches, but his last years were marred by criticism of how he had handled allegations of sexual abuse.
dc.creator: SAM ROBERTS

title: Steve Palermo, Umpire Whose Career Was Ended by a Bullet, Dies at 67
media.description: Steve Palermo, an American League umpire for 15 years, in 1982. He was shot in 1991.
description: Mr. Palermo was shot in 1991 while defending two waitresses from an attack outside a Dallas restaurant. He lived in chronic pain but had no regrets.
dc.creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

title: Powers Boothe, Actor Known for ‘Deadwood’ and Other Dark Roles, Dies at 68
media.description: Powers Boothe played Cy Tolliver, a saloon owner, on “Deadwood,” the HBO series.
description: The actor had lent his burly frame and Texas drawl to TV and films since the 1970s.
dc.creator: DANIEL VICTOR

title: Chuck Davis, Who Brought African Dance Traditions to America, Dies at 80
media.description: Chuck Davis in 2007. Far left, a DanceAfrica performance in 2015 featuring members of Bale Folclórico da Bahia, a Brazilian folkloric dance company. Left, the Zimbabwe troupe Umkhathi Theater Works at DanceAfrica in 2013.
description: Mr. Davis, founder of the DanceAfrica festival, lived by the mantra “Peace, love and respect for everybody.”
dc.creator: MARGALIT FOX

title: Yale Lary, a Force on the Detroit Lions’ Title-Winning Teams of the 1950s, Dies at 86
media.description: Lary punting for the Lions against the Los Angeles Rams in the 1960s. Lary developed his punting skills in junior high school by practicing outside his home at night.
media.credit: National Football League, via Associated Press
description: Lary, a Hall of Famer, was a safety and a punter. Although he was small, his “speed and quickness made him a real ballhawk,” said Raymond Berry, a Hall of Fame receiver for the Baltimore Colts.
dc.creator: RICHARD GOLDSTEIN

title: Mauno Koivisto, President Who Led Finland Into E.U., Dies at 93
media.description: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland speaking at a 1992 conference on European security in Helsinki.
description: Mr. Koivisto, the country’s last president during the Cold War, was seen as ushering in a new, freer era in a once-isolated nation.
dc.creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: Trump Told Russians That Firing ‘Nut Job’ Comey Eased Pressure From Investigation
media.description: President Trump met with Russian officials at the White House last week. American journalists were barred, but Russia released photographs.
description: The conversation reinforces the notion that President Trump dismissed him primarily because of the bureau’s investigation into possible collusion between his campaign and Russian operatives.
dc.creator: MATT APUZZO, MAGGIE HABERMAN and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

title: A Basquiat Sells for ‘Mind-Blowing’ $110.5 Million at Auction
media.description: “Untitled,” a Basquiat painting from 1982, sold for $110.5 million at Sotheby’s auction on Thursday night.
media.credit: 2017 The Estate of Jean-Michel Basquiat / ADAGP, Paris / ARS, via Sotheby's
description: Basquiat’s vibrant painting of a face in the shape of a skull set an auction record for a work by any American artist, beating Andy Warhol.
dc.creator: ROBIN POGREBIN and SCOTT REYBURN

title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Trump Administration Talent Vacuum
media.description: President Trump at the White House on Thursday.
description: Would you go to work for this president?
dc.creator: DAVID BROOKS

title: Opinion: We Aren’t Built to Live in the Moment
media.description: #NA
description: What best distinguishes human beings from other animals is our foresight, as scientists are just beginning to recognize.
dc.creator: MARTIN E. P. SELIGMAN and JOHN TIERNEY

title: Op-Ed Columnist: What’s the Matter With Republicans?
media.description: Paul D. Ryan, the House speaker, followed by Kevin McCarthy, the House majority leader, on Wednesday.
description: We need to understand what made Trump possible.
dc.creator: PAUL KRUGMAN

title: Comey, Unsettled by Trump, Is Said to Have Wanted Him Kept at a Distance
media.description: James B. Comey, then the F.B.I. director, after being called on by President Trump at a White House ceremony in January. Mr. Comey told a friend that he had hoped Mr. Trump would not spot him at the event.
description: The former F.B.I. director described being dismayed by the president’s attempts to build a personal relationship with him amid the Russia investigation.
dc.creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

title: Op-Ed Columnist: When the World Is Led by a Child
media.description: President Trump in Washington on Monday.
description: Reports that President Trump betrayed an intelligence source reveal the dangerousness of an immature man.
dc.creator: DAVID BROOKS

title: ‘This Doesn’t Sound Legal’: Inside Nike’s Oregon Project
media.description: In June 2015, Alberto Salazar watched as Galen Rupp competed in the 10,000-meter run at the USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships in Eugene, Ore.
description: A report by antidoping officials says the coach, Alberto Salazar, violated drug protocols with Dathan Ritzenhein, Mo Farah and other elite runners.
dc.creator: MATT HART

title: Canadian Colleges See Surge of Foreign Students. It’s Not Just Politics.
media.description: Maddie Zeif, a high school student from Vermont, plans to attend the University of British Columbia in the fall.
media.credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
description: The lower cost of higher education in Canada is attracting large numbers of Americans, as well as students from other countries.
dc.creator: CRAIG S. SMITH

title: Killing C.I.A. Informants, China Crippled U.S. Spying Operations
media.description: An honor guard outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing last month. The Chinese government killed or imprisoned 18 to 20 C.I.A sources from 2010 through 2012.
description: At least 18 C.I.A. sources were killed or imprisoned in China between 2010 and 2012, one of the worst intelligence breaches in decades. Investigators still disagree about how it happened.
dc.creator: MARK MAZZETTI, ADAM GOLDMAN, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and MATT APUZZO

title: ‘The Internet Is Broken’: @ev Is Trying to Salvage It
media.description: “I thought once everybody could speak freely and exchange information and ideas, the world is automatically going to be a better place,” Evan Williams says. “I was wrong about that.”
media.credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
description: The Twitter co-founder, Evan Williams, reflects on what the social media service has wrought on society and how he is trying to change things with Medium, the publishing site.
dc.creator: DAVID STREITFELD

title: Opinion: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Advice for Living
media.description: Ruth Bader Ginsburg appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee for her Supreme Court nomination hearings in 1993.
description: “It helps sometimes to be a little deaf” is wise counsel for marriage or for the Supreme Court.
dc.creator: RUTH BADER GINSBURG

title: Common Sense: Washington Post, Breaking News, Is Also Breaking New Ground
media.description: The newsroom of The Washington Post. Recent scoops about the administration have further enhanced what the news organization says is a highly successful strategy for impactful, profitable journalism in a digital age.
media.credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
description: As with Watergate, the paper’s scoops about the administration are helping shape the national conversation. They are also driving its digital success.
dc.creator: JAMES B. STEWART

title: The Health Issue: The Mystery of the Wasting House-Cats
media.description: #NA
media.credit: Mark Peckmezian for The New York Times
description: Forty years ago, feline hyperthyroidism was virtually nonexistent. Now it’s an epidemic — and some scientists think a class of everyday chemicals might be to blame.
dc.creator: EMILY ANTHES

title: In Iran, Heavy Voter Turnout Seen as a Plus for President Rouhani
